description:
I absolutely love this place! I happen to live in Japantown, and have checked out quite a few of the karaoke options here. 
If you like the idea of paying a lot of money, renting a room, and singing in the privacy of your small circle of friends, then Festa is NOT the place for you. 
But if you like the idea of singing in front of everyone in a small, intimate bar, then Festa is perfect! They have a huge selection of songs, including very recent ones. The staff are friendly and supportive. They make some pretty good cocktails for just $10 each, which is a good deal in many SF places. 
Best of all, I've been to Festa about 5 times, and every time, the audience is fun, kind, diverse, and very supportive. Really one of my favorite things to do in SF, believe it or not. Thanks, Festa!
author: Jim M.

description:
The staff here is incredibly rude (as other reviews have mentioned). I came with a group of friends for a birthday and it was quite apparent to everyone that they watered down all of the cocktails... completely unacceptable for the prices paid. 

Furthermore the staff blatantly lies about prices, I ordered one beer which cost $6. I later ordered 3 which ended up costing $20... somehow $2 extra magically added themselves to the bill, hmmmm.
author: Alex D.

description:
Pay $2 to wait an hour to single the song you requested and while you wait you can pay $15 for a single bottle of Sapporo and listen to the same drunk ass bro dude slur through 20 songs all in a row while everyone is yelling to get him off the stage and the person who's supposed to be DJing is nowhere to be found and the bro dude's frat bro falls on you and then gropes you while he apologizes emphatically for falling on you. Five songs play in a row but nobody comes to sing them and they refuse to skip the songs even though nobody is singing so drunk bro dude sings them. Someone takes your friends chair and when you politely tell him it's taken he gets instantly angry and rages at you. When your songs finally come on, they come on all in a row and everyone yells at you because how dare you sing 3 songs in a row (!), you're just like the drunk bro dude now! When the same thing happens to your friends, other people in the bar yell at them also. Oh, and only one of the two mics on stage actually works. 
High point of the evening was when someone sang "My Heart Will Go On." That should tell ya what you need to know! 
Enjoy!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
A cute little karaoke lounge located in the Japan Center Mall. We happened to randomly find this place when we were walking by the mall and heard a group loudly singing Bohemian Rhapsody. The inside is really nicely decorated with a city skyline silhouette and mood lighting, a stage in the corner and a bar on one side.

The staff is friendly and accommodating (the first time, we showed up a half hour before closing), and the drinks are decent - especially the sparkling rosé. The second time, we showed up at 8pm on a Saturday, and were the first ones in the bar. However, it quickly filled up - by 9, it was packed.

Pros: it's open until 3am! Most bars in SF will start kicking you out at 1:30, so it's nice to have a place that's open a little later.

Cons: each song costs $2, which is a little bit ridiculous, considering you're also probably paying for drinks.
author: Apoorva A.

description: $50 for a glass of wine, an old-fashioned, and 3 sodas. So stupid. Used to come here often but won't be coming here anymore.
author: k k.

description: Karaoke was great and so was the layout of the bar. I don't know what it is about bartenders in San Francisco and harassing patrons about tipping but this happened to me at another karaoke bar as well. So we closed out the tab and were drinking our drinks while waiting for our turn to sing and the bartender asks "why didn't you tip?" My friend said he had cash and was going to wait until we finished drinking our drinks. But same situation, different place. Bartenders pestering about tipping before we can even finish our drinks. It's not like I was waiting for them to turn around and book it while they weren't looking. Seriously if you hate your job that much that you need to harass people about "tipping" before they're done you need another job.
author: Kassandra M.

description: I've never felt compelled to write a review before but this one is special. I took my brother in law here for his birthday. When we were ready to leave I tried to close out my tab and I didn't recognize the charges so I asked the bartender about it. He replied, "I'm not fucking stupid, man!" I didn't think that reply warranted a tip so I provided him some feedback instead, "Don't be rude," and paid my full bill. He responded by following me out the door and challenging me to a fight. His exact words were, "Fuck you, man!" Fuck you, motherfucker!" This was pretty disappointing to say the least. I hope mall security checks the footage 'cause it's pretty clear based on where the security camera was positioned that he was acting aggressively. Festa is normally a nice place. Just check your bill. And beware the male API bartender with glasses on Friday night. He's got some anger issues.
author: Sam K.

description: Sad to post this because I used to love this place, but the bartender that works a later shift here is so unprofessional and rude. Charges you for drinks that you never ordered, and then gets violent, swears and yells at you when you point out the error. They need to replace that bartender, I will never go back as long as he is there, which is a shame because minus this bartender, it's a great place.
author: Akiko M.

description:
I'd be singing praises about this place if it wasn't for a few of the staff.

My friends and I were going around to a couple different places in Japantown and I looked this one up and saw on Yelp that it was open til 2 AM so we went in. It was about 12:45 AM. 

There were still several big groups there, a lot of them were pretty drunk and singing songs and stuff.  What you'd expect from a karaoke bar at this time of night. 

We ordered a few drinks and looked at the karaoke book.  I found a song and paid $2 to queue it in. 

At about 1 AM, the big group of drunk people were calling it a night so there were just my friends and a couple other groups.  But at this point, a few of the staff were sitting around the bar stools, just looking at us.  You know, as if to give the impression that they're just waiting for us to be done. I asked one of them what time they closed and they said 1:30 (not 2 AM).

So I decided to close out my tab since, whatever, it was getting late anyway.  A couple minutes after I paid, one of the older women of the staff (probably the owner?) came up to my table of friends with the receipt and plainly said "You didn't tip".

Mind you, all I ordered was a bottled beer and a canned soda (amounting to almost $17).  There was literally no service involved.  If it was a cocktail or something, sure.  If they actually brought our orders to the table instead of me having to go to the bar to get them, maybe that would warrant a tip for services.  But again, there was literally no service involved.  And since we were going to head out anyway, I paid $2 for a song that I wasn't even going to do.  But whatever, I gave her a single dollar. She snatched it and walked away without saying anything. Afterwards a couple of my friends even looked at each other like, "what the heck?"

We weren't even the last group to leave.  It was about 1:20 AM.  Someone change the hours listed here on Yelp. 

On the positive side, the karaoke song selection is one of the best and most diverse I've seen, and the books are very organized.  Also the decor is very nice.  It really is just too bad that the staff left such a sour taste.  Before the night was over, I was getting ready to tell everyone this was the place to go for late night karaoke in Japantown.  Oh well.
author: Daniel R.

description:
One of the only few initially who were there. If you've never been here before you might think it'll stay dead. But, damn.. on a Wednesday night it will get packed. You'll witness great and not-so great singers on the stage for karaoke. It's pretty fun. 

Bartender makes a decent mule. (:
author: Lilian L.

description: Small and intimate Karaoke bar is a fun place to hangout and sing your heart out.  Great staff and friendly customers.  Best bar in Japantown.
author: JP M.

description:
First of all be prepared to pay 2 bucks for every song. Very unusual for Karaoke. Prices are expensive.
We had an opened tab and tipped cash while we were ordering on that tab and also tipped additional to the 2 dollars of the song. Then we added about 10 percent tip when we closed the tab. We were told by a woman working behind the bar that this is not enough, so I gave her 10 bucks more. I also explained that I think this behavior is kind of weird and something like this never happened to me before, than she got completely angry, threw the 10 dollar in my direction and got crazy. I can't recommend this place in any way. Also there's a cat ON the bar lickin all the stuff that is within its reach, disgusting. My recommendation: Visit any other karaoke bar just not this one.
author: Valentin F.

description: Just visiting from Sunnyvale! Fun atmosphere,fun customers,and attentive bar tenders. Hopefully I'll be able to come again!
author: Aubrey J.

description: It was fun place to be! Good martinis and people happy and singing together! Great place for socializing although thy might be too drunk and not remember you next day! I will go there again!!
author: Mikiko O.

description:
100% not the spot for sake bombs (my #1 reason for the poor rating)

Ordered 5 sake bombs
Pours 1 bottle of Sapparo ($10) 1/5 each glass + 5 shots of sake (no idea price)
Charges me $64.....wth????

Talk about Las Vegas price gouging 

Overall Thoughts

Hard pass on this spot for sake bombs. Next time, i'll order it a la carte and save myself at least $40
author: Eddie W.

description:
This place! Do you want to feel like you're at a random karaoke bar in Asia during the Vietnam/Korean War?

This is the deal about this joint:
1) It's a small room with lots of nonjudgmental patrons just laying their hearts on the table via karaoke
2) Friendly Japanese ladies serve you simple drinks that get the job done
3) It's mostly Asian folks with random old Caucasian men singing their Frank Sinatra and country songs
4) The songbooks are pretty much large phonebooks straight out of the 80's (but do have lots of new songs)
5) The random city skyline decor is unassuming and nothing special, but it somehow adds to the random melting pot timeless charm this place has
6) It's in the heart of Japantown, surrounded by lots of delicious points of interest

For a good time and possibly a look into the past where cultures mesh over singing, check out Festa!
author: Marlon T.

description:
Remember when you were a tyke and you couldn't stop singing your favorite song...over and over again...like literally not stop? No matter if you were trailing your Mom at the grocery store, taking a bubble bath until your hands turned into large prunes, or getting your dinner taken away because you wouldn't stop? Well Festa provides you the opportunity to re-capture some of that unbridled joy that comes from musically expressing yourself.

Festa is an open environment with a small stage in the back of the room and the obligatory bar to the far right(#LiquidCourage). From the several times I have been here over the last few years, I can attest that in general a small encouraging community comes together every time you I have come here. You will hear everything from the latest Pop, 70's and 80's classics, to country being sung here on a daily basis. 

Service has been generally present and non-obtrusive which is a good thing in my song book. It's 2 smackers a song, which is reasonable, and their drinks are reasonably priced. If "Total eclipse of the heart" has been burning a hole in your soul to be unleashed then Festa should be one of your musical therapeutic options.
author: Dennis W.

description:
Festa is a little intimate karaoke place you go to when you have mastered your karaoke skills at a less classy karaoke place. A place to spend a few hours here listening to above average singers while sipping on reasonably priced cocktails and beer. 

My gripe with this place is more around the system. While I get the system is meant to be fair, there is room for improvement when our larger group only gets in 1 song per hour while a single guy gets in twice as many songs. We came with a group of 7 people around 9pm on a Saturday. Because of Festa's system, our first song came on a little after 10. Our next song came on around 11:30. We were there a total of 4 hours and got to sing 4 songs. Since most of the songs were either solos or duets, only about 2/3 of our group got to sing. I suppose it's not so bad if I pretend that I am at a bar drinking and listening to an entertainer. Most of the singers were either practically semi-pro or at the last, in tune and high energy.
author: Judy C.

description: Hands down the best karaoke bar in town! Cosy vibe and super friendly crowd. Go there ready to make friends and sing your heart out! The place is small enough that participation is basically required even if you don't have the best voice!
author: Cynthia M.

description: Awesome karaoke bar. Fun and cozy with tasty cocktails. Perfect place to rent out for a party!
author: Janny J.

description:
Festa had really unleashed the inner karaokeeee in meeeeeeee. 

Even though the title calls it a wine and cocktail lounge, Festa is really a karaoke lounge. Located on the second floor, inside the Kinokuniya Building in Japantown, this small little place is where I conquered my fear of singing in front of a crowd. It is just one room, with a stage and bar. No hiding from strangers in private rooms like many karaoke places. This place is definitely not for those that shy from singing and yet, small enough to overcome that hurdle a little more easy. 

At $2 per song, you're able to belt your lungs out. There are folders of thousands of popular songs in English and Japanese. I think I've even seen a Chinese song accidentally put on once. There are two mics on stage for you to sing duets, but not enough for boy band hits :|...unless you share mics. I did find that the volume for the music is too quiet for rock songs. The one unfortunate thing is that it's CASH ONLY to sing. So make sure you bring your dolla bills or get ready to sing a few if you have larger bills!

I love the decor of the stage. There fiber optic lighting above to emulate singing under the stars. The mini city back drop makes you stand out in front of the crowd. If it's your first time, you'd probably want to come Sunday-Wednesday when it's less crowded. Thursday-Saturday though.....it gets crowded. And I mean really crowded to the point where people have to stand in the hallway to wait for people to leave before finding a seat to sit. The place is small, probably a 40 crowded capacity, so if you're claustrophobic this is not somewhere you want to walk into. 

Drinks here are alright. $5 for green tea. Cocktails are reasonably priced between $9-10. I recommend the Lychee Mojito and Peach Bellini. Shots of spirits I believe are $12. Ordered Long Island once and it was mostly soda so I say stick with their house cocktails. 

Big thanks to my duet partna, Rodney H, for introducing me to this place. Great atmosphere and welcoming crowd makes for a comfortable place to sing your heart out!
author: Stan L.

description:
I can't believe I have never written a review for Festa before even though I've been coming here for several years. Located upstairs inside the Japantown mall, it's an open space(not the type of karaoke place with private rooms) with a bar on the right side. There's a small stage in the front of the room with a TV monitor to the side which displays your song's lyrics.

This a fun, supportive environment where you'll hear a wide diverse range of songs from 80's ballads to country songs to current pop songs. I have tried some of their cocktails and I'm not a big fan of them. 

Songs are $2 each, which is not cheap and not outrageous at the same time. The staff has always been very friendly.
Even if you're not the type to openly sing in front of strangers, I recommend you try Festa sometime because in general the crowd is encouraging and who knows, maybe you'll realize you're America's next great vocal talent.
author: Angela L.

description:
I'll admit I was pretty drunk when I showed up and I came here pretty much exclusively for the karokee so take my opinion with a grain of salt.

First - the drinks. They were fine I guess. I don't remember seeing a sign anywhere but I was told they had a one drink minimum. It wasn't very strictly enforced though because I had a friend or two who didn't drink anything. My first drink was some sort of lychee martini - I think it was good. My second drink was a jager bomb - pretty standard as far as I remember.

But the fun part about coming here is the karokee. It's $2 per song but it's totally worth it to go sing on their beautiful stage. It's decorated with a backdrop of a city, pretty lights, and even the night sky. You feel like you're a star on this stage. They also have a really good selection of songs. Overall a very fun experience. I would just recommend getting there earlier than midnight otherwise you'll only have time to sing one song, and that too only if you're lucky. 

Drinks are a bit pricey here so if I were you would pregame and then spend my money on songs!
author: Priyanka N.

description: This karaoke lounge and bar is super cute. We visited on a Tuesday night and at first it was pretty empty but around 9:15-9:30, all these people showed up and the place was packed. I used to like singing, but feel very self-conscious singing at karaoke bars. I'm new to it. I sang The Beatles' Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds. I was with Zane, George, and Craig. You have to buy a drink and singing a song costs $2. The atmosphere is cute. You will hear people singing Japanese songs.
author: Denise C.

description:
Festa is a fun quaint little Karaoke bar. My partner and I must have walked past it 100 times on our way to Sophie's Crepes. I thought it was big and foreboding, until I walked in there! 

Its adorable and tiny, and I wouldn't change a thing about the decor. The bartenders are really friendly. At first I was nervous about the signature cocktails, but they are actually delicious. Get the lychee martini! it sounds retro but it tastes DELICIOUS.

Go in relatively early (before 8) and you are guaranteed a good seat. Once we discovered Festa, we stopped going to the Mint for karaoke.
author: J M.

description:
Holy crap this place is amazing!

Usually Asian-style karaoke entails private song booths with tacky disco lighting and spending 40% of your time navigating an insanely complex song selection tool patented in Korea or Taiwan around 1992 that makes you appreciate the important of UX design. You barely end up socializing with the people you came in with, let alone anyone new.

Conversely, "karaoke bars" tend to involved 90% of the room feeling too squeamish to sing, leaving *that one guy* who's too drunk to care about how his screeching vocal chords are ruining our favorite songs, along with his dumb buddies cheering him along. The social problem is reversed: you get to spend plenty of time around other people, and end up loathing them.

Festa manages to bridge the social gap between these 2 archetypical karaoke experiences. Good drinks and tasteful decor allows more laid back vibe - every time I've been here I've met and talked with someone new. At the same time, the venue is small and relaxed enough that most people (or at least at least one person from most groups) ends up stepping up to sing, and everyone else is both supportive and truly appreciative.

A real gem of a place for a great night out.
author: David C.

description:
Festa is outstanding for karaoke. In my opinion, as good as it gets in SF. I've been to the Mint, Encore and Pandora, but this is hands down the most fun. The place is small, and you might wonder what you walked into when you first enter (it's in a shopping mall), but you'll soon realize why you're there. The people/regulars are great, the staff is super nice, and there is always some great talent (as well as some people who aren't, but that's with any karaoke spot).

Word of warning - bring cash. You do have to pay $2/song to sing, but this is pretty standard in SF. Also, if you like to sing a lot, the place isn't that big, so you'll be able to sing much more than once a night unlike at the bigger places around town.

Love, love, love Festa (disclaimer :and I'm not even much of a karaoke person)!
author: Derrick S.

description:
There are no separate private rooms here but you'll still like it. Not the typical karaoke joint that have rooms for rental and you pay by the hour - the typical karaoke experience. Here, it's all about the on-stage experience. Warbling and all this is the karaoke I go most often now.

Songs are $2 per, which is not cheap compared to other places. The drinks are not cheap either but also not super expensive. The money saved on not renting a room goes towards my drinks, yeah! Factor in the cost of renting a private room the bill for the night is actually cheaper.

And, like at any bar or club or lounge you should become a regular. Then, the bartenders will treat you better. I like the staff here, very friendly but not displaying favoritism like at other venues.

Note there are other karaoke joints in the Bay Area that has a stage for singing, some of them have rooms and some don't. I still prefer having both options so can pick and choose depending on the group. It's really a four star venue but the bartenders and owner earned the final star.

Bonus: youtube.com/TheKARAOKEChannel
youtube.com/singkingkaraoke
author: Peter L.

description:
Passing by this establishment numerous times and have never realized that this is actually a karaoke place. We came here the other day and for the most part enjoyed ourselves. The drinks were nothing special.

It was fun and wild in there, the space is actually quite small and intimate. The problem I have with this place is that it uses a karaoke machine. Pay 2 dollars per song, okay fair. Unfortunately it tells you nothing about how large the song queue is. Apparently there were 40+ songs still in the queue before ours, because we sat there for almost 2 hours and our song never came up. 

Also a really infuriating experience occurred - when one friend in our group left to use the bathroom, and a girl from another table tried to fight for his chair, claiming that our friend stole her chair. We nicely told her the chair was part of our table the whole time, and she finally backed off and drunkenly went back to standing near her group. 

I also observed a woman straddling her boyfriend while making out. I suppose people come to Festa extremely drunk, but I didn't need to see that. 

I can see myself coming back and probably enjoying it, but this place feels like a hit-or-miss.
author: Elisa L.

description:
Who'd thought? An open karaoke bar in SF in Japantown.  This is the place to be to get courage and sing in front of an audience.  It's a small place and just inside the mall.  So look carefully or you'll miss the place.  You just go up and choose your song and get the courage to sing.  

They require you to buy a drink to keep the establishment alive.  However, I didn't like any of their drinks.  They were too sweet and didn't try very hard to make the cocktails.  If you want to sing, you can come to this place, but just order something simple like a beer or some liquor that's just poured into a glass.  Choosing one of the cocktails isn't a good idea.  You'll be disappointed.  

It's fun if you want to perform in front of an audience, but I still prefer the room experience and not have to sing in front of strangers.
author: Shirley C.

description:
One of the best do-public-karaoke-on-a-stage venues I've been to. An interestingly mixed and very cordial crowd, and at least before midnight, not full of swaggering idiot drunks. (I mention this because I feel that there's a difference between being buzzed and goofy on stage, and wasted and screeching incoherently into a microphone.)  

Seating is cozy, but quickly fills up as the evening progresses. To sing a song, ya gotta pay $2. Which is ok by me, but a few people paid for a batch of songs and then sung several in a row - karaoke faux pas, Festa!

The emcee was surprisingly quiet, and also happened to be an excellent singer. I did think there were a few times where the music was mixed too far off from the singer's volume, and vice versa, but hey. It's karaoke.

As Kevin mentioned, they don't announce your song, name, or number... you have to either memorize and watch the queue carefully (where only your song number is displayed) or hop up there to do your thing once it appears on the screen.

Highlight: people singing songs where the verses are in Korean or Japanese, and then the crowd joins in for the English choruses.
author: Edison C.

description:
Put an i between the F and the E. What do you get?

F I E S T A!

Awwwwwwww snap.

I didn't know this little bundle of joy existed until just recently. 

Nestled in Japantown, this hidden karaoke bar is a complete gem. Practically any song you want to sing, from rock n' roll, to r & b, to alternative, Japanese pop, and even Disney songs. Their playlist runs the gamut and the crowd goes wild even if you hit absolutely the wrong notes. Approximately 80,000 songs are available in 5 different languages. $2 per song. 

Groupies in the houuuuuuse!

So if you ever want to feel like a superstar, step on to the stage and sing it LIVE! 

Oh c'mon, you know you do it front of the bathroom mirror anyway or in the car on the way to work.

Let your inner diva out!

It's a fun place for karaoke. The setting is intimate and the staff is incredibly friendly. Ambiance is conducive to slowwwwww jams; candle lit with a stage mimicking the city lights.

Go on. Let the superstar in you shine.

Open until 1am on most nights and until 2am on Friday and Saturday. 

Now pardon me while I belt it out to some Britney Spears.... a a a hem, "Hit me baby one more tiiiiiime!"
author: Ann S.

description:
Review #700 goes out to Festa! I don't know why, but it's seems very fitting that my first time here was with the Duke of Festa, Bobby L. He sure knows how to karaoke! Lol!

Located in the Japantown mall, it's a small bar with a karaoke stage. I've been to a couple bars with a public karaoke stage, but most of my karaoke experience in Japantown has been in private rooms, so this was a little new for me. I'm not much of a singer, but I love cheering on my friends!

We came by last Thursday and it was busy, but we managed to find a table shortly after we got there. A couple drinks, some karaoke songs, more drinks and even more karaoke songs and suddenly it was last call! Has it really been 3 hours already?! I guess I didn't notice since I was having so much fun!

The staff and bartenders are super nice and the atmosphere is very homey and cozy. Even though I'm used to private karaoke rooms, Festa has changed my mind about karaoke bars. You can have fun singing in front of strangers too! Well for me, cheering on friends in front of strangers! Lol!
author: Elena N.

description:
Hidden away gem.  My girlfriend and I were visiting San Francisco and met up with a cousin that lives there.  He took us out to some local places.  Then he brought us to this great place!

If you like an Intimate setting, Karaoke and Drinks, then this is the place to go!  It's got a warm family iconic feel. 

You will find yourself people watching, singing along, or becoming the singer.

If you are local or a visitor, then you must visit this place.
author: Manny S.

description:
We had an absolute blast at Festa recently. We came in for a drink right after the Cherry Blossom Parade. The venue was right up my alley. It's a small lightly-divey lounge bar with dim lighting and a vintage feel, it reminds me of Summer Place (see my other review) but with windows. 
Venue: 5 stars
Drinks: 5 stars. The Pomegranitini and the Blue Tokyo were both delicious.
Karaoke: 5 stars. We watched a soft-spoken, heavy-set gentleman blast the doors off of "Everything She Wants" by Wham. It was giving me life!
Uniqueness: 5 stars. For a bar to be great in my book, it need that something extra that sets it apart from other bars. Festa has a bar cat (5 stars) and it is the cutest and grumpiest bar cat you've ever seen (6 stars). Granted it was a Scottish Fold so it's ears are naturally pinned down, but that cat's face said it all: "NO." Adorable!!

I can't believe I've walked the Japantown Mall so many times without ever going into Festa. It will be a regular stop on all future visits!
author: Summer M.

description: A company I'm affiliated with bought this place out for the night. They kicked me and some others I was with out because a person I was with accidentally knocked over a drink. Seeing as we were paying them several thousand dollars to rent out their bar, and would happily have compensated them the cost of the single broken glass, I was pretty offended. Do not recommend, especially for rental purposes.
author: Charles W.

description:
I came with some coworkers on a Thursday night around 11PM. It was not crowded at all and I didn't have to wait long to sing my songs on stage. It's definitely better to go later at night. The staff is really funny and they'll jump on stage and sing as well if there's no one in the queue. 

The song list is older but kudos for providing Chinese, Japanese and Korean songs! I think it's a great place to come in a group. The lounge is cozy but for anyone with stage fright, it's always better to come with friends who will cheer you on.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Weirdly located karaoke bar in a mall somewhere I. Japantown. 

Make sure you have cash if you go here and plan on singing! $2 a song...

Fun place, been a couple of time and will probably go again because I can't resist getting up for a sing-song!
author: Sarah S.

description:
********************* 1225 ********************** 

   A cool karaoke place inside the Japan Town, tiny, and it was jam packed at 9:30 PM on a FRI night. A few tables, a small bar with less than 8 seats. Limited wines and cocktail list. 

   Capacity can not be more than 30 people.  I counted 40+ at the time I was there. I came in for a quick drink. They substituted the wine I ordered. I guess no one drink wine on a weekend night but me! Somm problem, ehhh! 

   The white bartender was nice and cute. Nice owner too, she remembers my friend. People were signing, laughing, and having a great time. Service was nice and fast. Just got into the bar to order your drinks was a struggle because it's too packed. I got a seat at the bar, and I got a few girls pushed me and knocked their giant handbags over me. I guess this is why I rarely go out anymore :-)

   If you like me, like a personal space, this is NOT for you. If you like to smell other people sweat and people screaming at your face. You would fit right in here. It's definitely a cool joint if you are into karaoke with a group of friends.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Festa is a fun little venue to sing and get your drink on. I didn't do much singing - I prefer watching others perform. 

Still, I had a good time. Drinks were unique (try the blue curacao and pineapple-infused Blue Tokyo), the venue was comfy, and the clientele was all there to have a good time. Maybe I'll go come back and sing Wham or something.
author: Casey S.

description:
I've been to Festa numerous times and I must say that performing karaoke there is not for the shy folks.  But if you are one, it's a great way to conquer your shyness and just let loose and have fun.

It took A LOT of visits for me to finally have to courage to go up and sing.  Keep in mind, I am not a singer, but I enjoy singing tunes while I'm driving so this was a way to share some of my favorites to the audience at Festa.  Of course once you get used to being up on their stage, you get really comfortable and then actually want to belt out tunes on a whim.  If you're just starting out, I really recommend going Sunday-Wed when it's not as busy and you can get in more than one song.  The crowds are usually full of regulars during these times and they are really cool folks.  The song selections are pretty extensive and they get updated periodically.

I don't drink much alcohol but they do have a nice menu of wine, cocktails, and beer.  So it's a great spot to take a group of friends or family for some drinks and entertainment.

I really have to thank Bobby L. for introducing me to Festa.  It's become a great new hangout for me with a great atmosphere, cool people, and fun musical entertainment.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Frank Sinatra probably started off small. It must have been on one of those tiny stages like they have at Festa - you're in the spot light, but it still feels intimate. The drinks are good, the crowd fun and relaxed. And they definitely get loose the later it gets.

Sadly, during my many visits there I only felt like Frank Sinatra ONCE - when I was performing a classic that I can't remember. Nowadays, I'm mostly content with sitting and enjoying the performances that range from close-to-ear-damage to San-Francisco's-Got-Talent.

Festa's extensive list of songs provide fun for nights to come. Get your Frank Sinatra on and hop on stage.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
BEST KARAOKE HAPPY HOUR IN THE CITY
---
THE DEETS:
- Waited with Rodney H for our reservations at State Bird Provisions
- In time for Happy Hour - free songs if you purchase a drink
- Sing in front of an audience type of karaoke
- Pay per song during non happy hour times
---
OVERALL:
- Would go again but only during happy hour. I'm not big on karaoke in front of an audience. I like those karaoke joints where you rent a room with friends and only your friends can judge you. Strangers scare me. Happy hour was fun because it was me, Rodney and the bartender. Good times!

#495
author: Marlyn A.

description:
Been here about a million times but had a HELLA bad experience tonight.  The girl working here tonight pissed me off. I walked in late on a Sunday night - place was very quiet and there was hardly a queue for songs.  My family was visiting from Puerto Rico and had never heard me sing, and had never seen karaoke. I said - is it OK for me to sing one song. This young girl working there (Caucasian) had such an attitude. She was drinking a beer, and made me buy an $8 water. After the transaction, she lectured me on how everyone has to order a drink. It was so awkward. I told her I had been there a thousand times and would be happy to pay extra to just sing - that we were full and weren't going to stay long. t could understand if the place wasn't empty, or if I hadn't already paid for the overpriced Voss water. More than the policy, she just gave me the heebie jeebies.

I'd like to emphasize that my issue was more with the *ATTITUDE* than the POLICY.
author: Andrew K.

description:
"Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name, 
And they're always glad you came." ..........(Gary Portnoy, "Cheers" theme song)

I dedicate my 300th review to a place that I've visited over 100 times, sang at least 100 songs, and probably drank 100 drinks.  Why did it take me long to write this?  I must've been busy on their stage, or taking it EASY!

What draws me here on a weekly basis is the cozy setting, their friendly staff, and of course...Karaoke.  I always feel at home here.    
I don't like singing in front of large crowds, and I usually prefer private karaoke rooms...but this place is intimate enough with a small lit stage, supportive crowd, and not bad of a sound system (considering the absence of a resident K-DJ).  Their extensive song selection isn't bad either.  They update with new songs every so often, but I tend to sing the older stuff anyway.  This place can get really packed on weekends, so don't expect to sing your songs close to closing time.  

The bartenders are very down-to-earth, sincere, helpful, and fairly quick in making drinks upon order.  They do an exceptional job keeping the place clean, accommodating all their customers, creating a safe and fun environment for all.  
This place is great for small private parties too.  Masae and staff are excellent in catering to their guests.  

Some people call this place FIESTA on accident, and I think they nail it every time I hear that.  If I could come here every night, I would!  Actually, I think I have in multiple weeks.  I just hate leaving my heart in San Francisco.  Thanks to my duet partner, Ting A, for the introduction!
author: Bobby L.

description: Love this place. Karaoke is free until 9pm, and since most folks don't want to sing, that means more for me! ;) The space is small, but in a truly cozy way, and the staff is always friendly. Definitely my go-to for a drink and sangin'!
author: Shendi X.

description: Horrible service from your bartender. Rude & was poorly trained; drinks were eyeballed thus resulting in an awful taste. Couldn't get his name but he was an Asian male with ears piercing, wore a beanie (what a way to represent your business) definitely wouldn't come back and wouldn't recommend this place because of this half assed bartender.
author: Rj L.

description:
Came on a Wednesday night fairly early, which meant basically having the place to ourselves. Cute little karaoke bar. I have never in my life had to pay $2 per song at a karaoke bar. I can see how having to pay per song would limit the number of songs people would sing on a busy night, but if we are the only two people in your bar, is it really necessary for us to pay?

The drink menu was on point, but the appetizers we ordered were not. Edamame was soggy and watery and gaucamole out of a container and stale chips....YUCK. 

$22 to sing 4 songs, have one glass of wine and eat some soggy edamame.
author: Christine E.

description: Great place to have some drinks and sing w some friends. The crowd is great and very supportive. Luckily I have an amazing voice so I always bring the heat. Great for a quick pop in, drink and song!
author: Manuel U.

description:
I will admit that before going here I'd only done karaoke once. I'm pretty sure I'm tone deaf, but the nice thing is at 1am after a bunch of drinking, it doesn't matter. Just sing with conviction and everyone will cheer you on.

I find the location (inside this odd indoor strip-mall thing) kind of weird, and the place is small and tacky - but maybe that's part of the charm?

Nothing else stands out about the place - so I'm only giving it 3 stars - but perfectly OK place to take a few friends out to get your karaoke kicks on.
author: Joshua B.

description: The bartender was SUPER RUDE! He seemed very racist and only responded to Asian customers. And he kept making up rules about singing a song like each person has to pay  $2 for singing (even if duet) and also a minimum amount of drinks. If you are non-Asian,  I do NOT recommend you go here!
author: Mahla S.

description:
Be careful: if you open the tab, they are likely to overcharge you "accidentally". Double-check your bill and do not hesitate to ask questions.
Other than that, this is an average option. It's a relatively cozy bar, to be sure; but it's "forte" is karaoke, and let's face it, most people should not be singing out loud. Unfortunately, there's no escape once you are in Festa, and you'd be exposed to this cacophony all night if you stay there. By the way, if you do decide to try yourself out at the stage, there's a $2 charge per song, payable in cash only.
What else... drinks, even when you are charged for them correctly, are still overpriced. They have a weird policy of charging $10 per person if you have a really large group. The owner is a nice lady but perhaps it's time to change some rules in that place.
author: Evg R.

description: Came here with a few friends. Had an absolute blast. Good song selection overall, and the crowd was definitely having a good time. The place is small so it can get packed pretty quickly. A lot of fun to enjoy as either an audience member or as a singer.
author: Dudley F.

description:
I rolled to Fiesta with the Yelp Posse after the Elite event at Barrelhouse . 
Its Bobby L. hangout and that boy can SING!!! Its a small intimate place in J Town . It reminded me of one of the Karaoke Places from the movie Duets. 

Its a place to have a few drinks cut loose and just have fun and sing .

 It has a Unisex Restroom. 

The Bartenders run the Karaoke Machine.

At  times its can be a Yelpers Hangout.
author: Eugene L.

description: i had a great time at festa lounge! it was definitely smaller than i had expected, but since it was coachella weekend 1, it wasnt as packed as it usually is, i think! yay! the drinks are pretty expensive - after tip it was $70 for 2 negroni's and 2 macallan 12's. kinda pricey right? oh wellll. it's also $2 to request songs which i've never seen at other places. song selection is definitely not great, and everything is bound in book form by song title, which makes it difficult to find songs... oh well. but the crowd is super energetic and friendly, and everyone is clearly there to have a great time. would definitely come back for more!
author: Christina L.

description: The bar itself is not bad. It is billed as a Karoake bar so I will address that. It is very small and typically you get a group of really drunk people that just scream any nonsense. In between though, there are some descent singers. The beer choice is very limited though and I agree that their system is ridiculous. I read about Judy C who said that of all those at her table, only a couple got to sing. Yeah, that is so ridiculous. So if you come with friends, the chances of each of you singing are quite slim because they take only 1 song per table per rotation. YES! DON'T GO. And to make matters worse, one of the bar tenders, a skinny slimy kind of guy who admittingly has been fired from his last 2 places,  gets up and sings several times and tells the crowd it was by request...yet noone knows who requested it. LOL. The place has potential however, It is horribly run. While I am at it, why are there so many 'employees' who arent working sitting at the corner of the bar taking up space, not drinking, not providing service, nothing!?! Save yourself the frustration and go somewhere where they have a clue.
author: Respectfully Yours Y.

description:
C'mon...who doesn't love singing in front of a bunch of strangers? 

A few things...
*pretty small place...only about 10 tables. Would suggest getting there before 9p on the weekends if you want a seat. 
*each song is $2, but the list is long. They have every decade, as we'll as show tunes. 
*affordable drinks...and pretty quick service at bar and table. 

Overall...great service, fun atmosphere and large song book. Time to get your sing on!
author: Dru M.

description: This place used to be great but they book private parties every night so every time you show up you can't go.
author: Alex C.

description:
This place is tiny so don't plan on bringing a whole army of friends here. I'm glad we didn't have a huge group with us or it would've been tough to get our songs played. They charge $2 a song and they don't announce your name so you really have to pay attention if you want to sing. The song selection is pretty good. They even have songs in Japanese if that's your thing. I witnessed several people singing songs in Japanese here - bartender included.

There's a one drink minimum so be ready to shell out at least $9 for a cocktail. The bartenders are pretty good here. We didn't wait very long to be served and they seemed happy to take our orders.

We must've went on a pretty good night because it wasn't overly crowded until later and most of us got our songs played rather quickly. 

I didn't realize they had a bathroom here until the night was almost over. Instead, I ran downstairs into the Japan Center mall.

I'd probably go back but I don't know how many songs I'd sing since they'd already be getting my money for a drink and at least one song.
author: Amy J.

description:
To view the entire review, check out my blog (link in my profile)

What an absolute blast! Nice ambiance, a welcoming vibe (especially for a trembling first time karaoke singer like myself), nice drink selection and awesome bartenders! 

Atsuko, one of the bartenders, was so friendly made us feel right at home. Service was quick even as the place started to heat up. And you didn't have to wait all night before your song came up like some places I've been in LA.

Bravo! I'll definitely be back!
author: Paul B.

description: The drink menu said a Saketini are $9 and that the Classic Mohito are 10 and required a CC to keep the tab open. We drank our drinks and listen to a couple sang and flipped through the sticky booklets. Closed our tabs and the total was $51! WTF?! Wrong tab we thought and explained what we ordered. She said it was 2 of each but we only wanted one of each and that's all we had. GREEDY and a RIP OFF! She said sign it and she will give me the difference. She gave me $25 in cash and I told her this isn't the correct charges and explained how much she owes me. She gave me my money but this place can go to hell and die! And the employees kids can have cancer and die!
author: Shy S.

description:
It's been awhile since I've actually gone to any other Karaoke place because my friends LOVE LOVE LOVE Festa, so I almost can't compare.  

First off, I almost always have a super fun time.  

Second, it's a lounge, not private rooms, so it's definitely the place to go if you either a) want to sing in front of a room full of strangers, or b) you are with just one or two others and it would be a little weird to book a private room elsewhere in Japantown.  

Third, it's pretty cozy, and the drinks are pretty good (both wine and cocktails, like lychee martini).  I also like the city skyline background when you sing, as it makes for great photos!  

Finally, they do a decent job of taking your requests and rotating between different tables to make sure different groups get a turn.  (Of course the negative side of this is that if you have multiple people in your group, it can take awhile for you to get to sing).  

But it's a decently up to date song list (not the most current songs though),  $2 a song, and about $10 a drink.  For a few hours of entertainment it cost us $25 apiece so that seems okay.  The crowd definitely ebbs and flows - you have your regulars who sing Frank Sinatra and other oldies - but as always, the fun quotient depends on who else is there too.  It definitely gets more crowded sometime around 11 pm, and then it can be standing room only.   The only other thing I'll note is that it's in Japan Center, and it can take awhile to navigate between those buildings!
author: Vivian W.

description:
I've been passing the place by in J-town for a good number of years, without realzing what this place really was. 

After an evening of hopping lounges and karaoke bars, my group decided to head here to finish off the night. The prices are a lot cheaper than renting private rooms and the stage and lounge area is intimate enough to where you don't feel intimdiating standing up on stage. I thought the sound equipment was also a lot better, although, a few additional screens (namely in front of you) would have been better than having to keep looking off to the side on a smallish screen on a shelf for lyrics. 

Again, great intimate lounge with some of the best singers I've heard yet (aside from Martuni's) and at only $2 bucks a song, you truly only pay for the songs you end up singing. The drinks are obviously still pricey as with any bar/lounges are, however, since I'm not into drinker, I was able to just pay for my songs and then leave whenever I wanted. 

Overall, it was a great first experience here and I even made some a few fans at the end of the night! :)

PS. If you're going to be doing karaoke late night 9pm+, I highly recommend parking in the J-town garage which charges only $1 late night hours. It's a lot more secure than parking on the street around here!
author: Petra S.

description: A fun place. Introduced to this rad location by quite the exquisite free-spirited gypsy woman I dated briefy last year on her and my 1st night out, I've been coming here since on quite a many adventures. Five stars for good vibes and alright drinks. Minus one star for them overcharging me on drinks I didn't order by careless servers. Minus one star for lack of American beer choices. Through and through, a place I'll recommend.
author: Richard R.

description: My friends and I came here on a Thursday night and we had an absolute blast. The bartenders were super helpful and incredibly nice. The drinks were delicious and the choice of songs was vast. I'd highly recommend this location if you're looking for a great time with friends in a more in intimate, clean, and fun setting! Can't wait to come back
author: Kaci B.

description:
I have never karaoked like this before!  A stage?!  Singing in front of total strangers?!  What happened to the little private rooms with the disco ball and plasma TV with strange Asian music videos????  

Needless to say, I was a little intimidated.  I was there with the veterans!  

First of all, you have these 4 huge song books.. alphabetized by song title, artist, or language.  You pick a song, write it down on a piece of paper (I think it's $2 a song?), and wait for your turn.  It was sooooo nerve-wracking!  I was scared I was going to crack.. or worse.. what if I get boo'ed off?!  

But I had such a blast!  The first time is always the scariest, but everyone was there cheering everyone else on.  Plus, it's not a very place.  There's a full bar, maybe 5 tables with booth seating, the small stage, and a bathroom. You'll probably never see these people again, so it's ok to embarrass yourself.  AND, they were all pretty drunk, so everyone's just having a grand ol' time :)

I love it.  I don't think I'm ever going back to traditional karaoke :)
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Awesome song selection in 3 languages!

I went here with the regulars (the ones that have their own song book selection) and i had such a great time belting it out!  The weekday crowd was non judgmental and encouraging.. Someone even asked me to sing again!

I had a delicious bellini, which was $10.  I believe there is a one drink minimum.  And Atsuko, one of the bartenders, was fun to hang out with.  I'll definitely come here again!
author: Vira P.

description:
True Pros
-Very small & intimate venue which means lots of song time
-Very friendly staff who check in occasionally
-Never too crowded
-Dancing, wandering, & having fun with the mic are all totally acceptable (no uptight dj)

True Cons
-Drinks could be stronger
-Single venue?
-An additional mic and air instruments would make it better
-Fancy cityscape background

So why 5 stars...
You come with a party of 6+ people, and the stage is pretty much yours. It's just always fun.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Came here on my birthday last summer with a few friends after dinner and never had the chance to review. It's  a very small and intimate place where people can get drinks and karaoke which is located inside of Japantown plaza. 

Although most karaoke places have many rooms where people sing for their own privacy. Not this place!! You pick a song from the folders and when it's your turn, you go up to the small stage and you sing in front of everyone. It's very entertaining just watching those people sing no matter how good or how bad they sing. You have to be 21 to get into this place if you want to sing since they serve alcohol drinks. 

If you order drinks, it's a bit pricy. I order Pear Cosmo for $9. I order this drink cause I never cosmo with pear flavor and also thought it'll be a sweet kind of cocktail. I was sure wrong. You can really taste the volka strong alcohol taste which made it harder for me to drink.
author: Julie N.

description:
$12 for a well dirty martini? Unless their bottom barrel vodka is Grey Goose, me thinks not. 

Still a great spot for a fun night of karaoke, but some recent service failures have taken a bit of wind from out of my sails.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Great little karaoke bar!! Extensive song list to choose that perfect song and impress the crowd with your awesomely alcohol induced voice!! Bartender was nice and very attentive when drinks were running low.
author: Leigh W.

description: Apparently I came on a weird night, where the karaoke was mainly weird oldies. Not much Japanese karaoke.
author: Billy F.

description:
Small, intimate Karaoke Bar upstairs in the Japan Center in the Kinokuniya building near the internal bridge overpass. 

Japanese owned. The older couple sitting at the end of the bar helps with the welcome feel, with the classy lady smiling you in, and the gentleman sitting next to her at the end of the bar, getting up and singing old favorites in the slow moments. The tall, thin, younger male and female bartenders are Japanese, too. 

Huge songbook with many current releases in large binders. Lotsa J-Pop, but tons of American favorites, too, in any genre. 

One small stage with a small LCD monitor for the singers. A handful of tables and a small bar. 

Most Americans call this activity like they're lifting and hauling a redneck, or "Carry Okie".   

The Japanese pronunciation is like them telling you the vehicle they drive is in good condition, or "Car, uh, Okay!"

This place is packed on the weekends, so try coming on a school night for more singing opportunities. No private rooms.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Have you ever waltzed into a karaoke bar and immediately graced the stage with one of your favorite songs without even having to request it? It's the way to go, folks. And I speak from my experience at Festa!

We had just done room-style karaoke at a random sketchy place a little further down Fillmore. The lack of English selection there was just not cutting it for us, so we peaced out after an hour in search of something else in the area. Walking on Post, I saw the sign for Festa, and remembered my cousin had always raved about that place. We decided to hop into Japantown to check it out.

The minute we walked in, I randomly saw my supercool friend Jason C. on stage singing with a drunk dude and instantly knew it was gonna be a good night. He saw me just as the next song he requested--Total Eclipse of the Heart, one of my go-tos--was coming on, and called me up to sing with him. So I did! Ain't no thang. The crowd loved it... just sayin'. That's how I roll at karaoke.

But seriously. This spot has officially won me over as my favorite karaoke bar in SF. It's a bit smaller than the other ones I've been to, but as a result there are less people and you have more chances to sing. I think the size also makes it's impossible for you to have left the bar without making new friends (maybe it was just the night I went, but the crowd vibe here is super fun). There's also a full bar with the friendliest people ever serving you huge Sapporo beers ($10). The twinkling city skyline backdrop on the stage is not as cheesy as it sounds and only adds to the magic.

And of course, you never know who you'll run into here. Shoutout to my buddy Jason C. Til we sing together again ;). Festa forever!
author: Kate V.

description:
This is one of those places where you have to pay to sing.  Luckily, it's up-front.  Unluckily, everything is pretty expensive here.

There's also not a KJ in the traditional sense.  It's not really clear who is running the karaoke and it might as well be a machine--no engagement with the crowd.

But it's a neat lounge-type atmosphere and the crowd was really energetic and supportive.  Might try it again.
author: Reese H.

description:
Quite possibly the best karaoke spot in the entire Bay Area... 

Nestled in a Japantown shopping center, this is an itty bitty bar. You could easily walk by and miss it altogether, especially since it doesn't get bumpin' until way after all of the surrounding stores are closed. If you walk in and see an unidentified skyline on the small stage, you know you've come to the right place.

What I like best about this particular karaoke joint is the fact that everyone pays $2 to sing and there's no cheeseball KJ there to sweet talk. Just write down your song selection, hand it to the bartender and they'll queue it up and add the monies to your overall tab. Brilliant! This way, it's all fair and square.

I've been here a handful of times and it's always a blast. Since the setting is so intimate, it's impossible not to get  caught up into whatever song the person on stage is singing. Definitely a great place to make new friends. Or run into existing ones, like I did the other night when I ran into Bobby L and a few other South Bay yelpers :) BTW, what were you guys doing so far from San Jose so late????
author: Abby S.

description: So unfortunate. I've been here a couple of times and in both cases I'll just say "money talks". This time around my wife and I came in for her birthday and paid $6 and didn't get to sing anything after more than an hour. But the worst part was that our lack of singing was a result of no actual order of operations. The guy next to me submitted a song and sang 5 minutes later. It's app about luck of the draw with this place... Or favoritism... Or.. Who knows? But either way, if you're not "in" or lucky, you're not singing.
author: Ty A.

description:
Anyone who knows me well knows that I LOVE to karaoke.  Though I usually prefer singing in a room with just my friends, there's something exhilarating about getting up in front of a crowd of strangers.  I've introduced many friends to Festa and everyone has enjoyed coming here, as far as I know.  They keep pretty up-to-date on their songs, but also maintain a nice list of the classics.  

So, this is how it works: you write your song on a slip of paper, hand it to the staff at the bar, and wait nervously for your song to play.  While waiting and feeling somewhat regretful for the situation you just put yourself in, you end up downing a beer or taking a (few) shot(s) to calm your nerves.  By the time your song is up, you're too buzzed/drunk to even care; as far as you know, you rocked it!  It's a formula for a great night, if I do say so myself.

Drinks are a bit pricey here; you can easily rack up a hefty bill between drinks and songs, which cost $2 each (free before 9 on M-Th, I believe).  It's always a fun time though, and the patrons here are always nice and supportive of whoever is up on stage singing, so don't be shy!
author: Thi D.

description:
Nice ambience and owner/bartender Ken is fun and down to earth. The other bartender doesn't speak english well....or at all? It took a while to explain/ask her if they had Level Vodka because she didn't understand me (it wasn't loud in the bar, there were only 3 other people aside from our group of 5). 

I asked for Belvedere instead but she couldn't read the labels of vodka that was on the shelf. I kept telling her "the last one......the only one on the shelf that has the letter 'B'!). She went down the line, pointing at each and every bottle while asking me if that was Belvedere. Oy vey.....

The song selection was good and the sound system was decent. The only thing I didn't care for was the stage that you have to stand on to sing. Luckily for shy people like myself, Ken has 2 cordless mics set up in addition to the mics on the stage. I was able to sing from the comfort of our table. 

Songs are $2 each but they do have a Karaoke Happy Hour that runs from Mon to Thurs, 7:30pm to 9pm. Just mention "yelp" to get in on that deal.
author: Cin T.

description: This is such a fun venue with groups of friends. No judgments, free to sing, dance however you like.  Even if there are judgments, you wouldn't even know or care lol.  The only drawback is the limited seatings considering how tiny the venue is. Just be patience for opened spots. Another is their process of songs sign ups, make sure to give them the numbers to the correct song from the right booklet! Won't mind coming back again.
author: Nel L.

description:
If you're looking for a chill, divy karaoke bar, this is your place!  It's a very small, and intimate establishment, but the perfect place if you just want to have some drinks, sing and have fun.  The crowd is mixed, so you'll get a wide range of songs sung throughout the evening.

You pay per song, and songs are $2 each.
author: Audrey C.

description: This place is in the mall so people that come here purposely do.  It's a tacky karaoke stage and the bar itself is really small.  I can tell the service is good - they keep it clean by clearing alcohol glasses and wiping down the tables.  I probably would not come back unless the whole place was rented out with my friends, which means a private karaoke room would be more efficient.
author: Chris L.

description:
The first time you walk in here, you might think it's pretty darn small and will be too cozy with the rest of the audience. I mean, we don't go to a karaoke bar to show off our singing skills and perhaps dancing talents. No, we come here to have a good time, laugh about our tone deafness, and share our drunken embarrassment on stage in front of strangers, who are also doing the same.

It's pretty inmate here, I wish it was bigger or that they'd expand it a little. The bar area could be minimized to increase the efficiency. The same could be said about the narrow hallway as well. What's really funny is that the sound of the place could be projected out onto the streets, and delight people passing by.

Drinks weren't cheap, and the bartenders had a hard time keeping track of who bought which drinks, so our tabs were mixed up pretty well at the end of the night. They have every single song you can think of. The stage is tiny as well, but we managed to fit 8 people up there, although it was a very tight squeeze. They charge for each song that you sing, which is a first for me at a karaoke place. You mean I have to PAY to humiliate myself for other people's entertainment? I guess it's to limit people from singing too much

Pretty cool place to come and hang out at.
author: Phan H.

description:
There are certain songs that are best left in the privacy of your own shower. These are examples of what you shouldn't sing at Karaoke lounges:

1. Depressing songs -- i.e. I will remember you by Sarah Mclachlan. You may have the voice of an Angel my dear, but this song gets everybody down.

2. Super looong songs -- remember Meatloaf's I will do anything for love? yeah. it goes on F-O-R-E-V-E-R.

3. Prince's songs complete with an exact rendition of Prince's voice. (same goes for the Bee Gees!) Just DON'T. Unless you're cute like my sis then it's okay.

This intimate lounge sure brings the fiesta to Japantown. It's located inside the Kinokuniya strip mall. There isn't a happy hour for drinks, but if you come between 8 - 9pm on Mon - Thurs, songs are free just mention yelp. Otherwise, It's $2 per song (good luck finding it!) if you're like one of those people with crappy memory like I do who can't remember the artist or the exact song title, the thick binder of songs will have you searching for awhile. Plus, you have to watch the screen when your song comes up and make a dash for the stage since there isn't an official DJ here. 

You'll have a good time here for sure! The crowd is supportive and it doesn't matter if you've fallen off your chair twice (some guy, not me!) or can't carry a tune, people won't judge you here. Think of it as training ground before unleashing the karaoke queen in you at The Mint.
author: Janice C.

description:
"So I put my hands up, they're playing my song..." YEP. My friends and I sang Miley Cyrus and so much more.

Our large group came here on a Friday after dinner together and found this to be one of the better places to spend the rest of our night. There were so many music choices and all different types of people in here. My white friends were so shocked to find other white people who were able to sing in Japanese and Chinese - they were confused. REALLY CONFUSED. It was great! 

My friend really wanted to come here because as a frequent customer, she loves hearing one of the bartenders sing and HE WAS REALLY GOOD! 

PLEASE - for the sake of everyone else. If you ever come here, sing an upbeat song. You should only be allowed to sing a depressing song IF you are amazingly good and have soul. Otherwise, spare us - we're all trying to have a fun time! 

Overall, I think everyone had a great time. Great for large groups of people, but not too large because it does get a little crowded. It started filling up around 9:30 p.m. 

They also have lychee martinis here - YUM! Perks of asian-inspired bars...
author: Mimi V.

description: Expensive drinks. $2 per song. Will not provide free ice water without harassing you about the drink minimum (which I had already met in spades).  Attitude after receiving 16% tip on sub-par service.  Normally I have fun here but it seems lately the service/vibe has been totally off.
author: Ernie A.

description:
4.5 stars as a karaoke spot, but I'll give them 5 because it's more than a karaoke bar: it's an awesome place to have some drinks and watch people with wonderful voices sing. It's small and it's not too loud. So, you can have drinks with friends in a comfortable environment, and enjoy the show. The staff is friendly, and the regulars are hilarious -- they clearly practice for performing on the stage at Festa. Drinks are a little pricey for the quality, but you're getting a show too.

Really fun place!

My one complaint is that they charge $2 a song after a certain hour (8pm?) even if there is clearly no one singing and few people in the bar. I'm grumbly about disincentivizing people from singing, when I came there to watch people sing (and that's why I'm paying a little more for booze).
author: Jacqueline W.

description:
Wow! Ok years ago I used to come here...it was double the size and served shrimp treats...super cheese...
Fast forward Now.....Much Much Better Cool intamate stage....Love the Background...
I had a really Great Time here.
The Bartendars were Very Friendly. Drinks are Pricey but that's exspected...I think its odd to charge $2.00 per song when people are paying 10.00 a pop for coctail s , I understand more when its slow...but one has to Pay to Play ...its all Good....
I had a Blast , the Cat's I ended up chatting with were so much fun and were such nice people.They come here alot, and geeze they had Amazing Voices...so so fun....I rarely get out...They were forsure the Big Bonusus to meet.Thanx so much for not laughing at me singing buck owens stuff....Im glad the guy from Texas moved here...R&B suits him well...Lol, fantastic Voice.....
I was stopping in for one Cocktail after the Bathhouse and ended up staying until 2:00....
Im. Not sure about others but
The Staff was very very friendly..singing was absolutely free until 9:00.
Its 2014 get over yourself for complaining...shame on the Negitive reviewers....
Thanks japantown for keeping this place inside....keep laughing
author: Connie B.

description:
Ben B said it best when he described Festa as "looking like an airport watering hole in Tulsa mixed with a stage borrowed from bad nineties stand up."

I couldn't describe the place better myself, and I won't try. Walking into this scene made me instantly melancholy and perhaps a little icked out, but I knew there was a bigger reason for my presence, and it wasn't the decor. Karaoke!

When I discovered the drink list and the option of a lychee martini, things were looking up considerably. Especially when the bartender humored my request to modify the recipe ever so slightly. My drink was fantastic, so I had two more.

Liquid courage on the rise, I jumped on stage with my cohorts for a group effort and then once more on my own. The friendliness of the crowd encouraged these actions; everyone there was like one big support system and the biggest fan of whoever was on stage at any given time. 

Songs were $2 a pop, which could add up quickly depending on how much you like the limelight. Our final group song started playing only after we started to make our way towards the exit. In unison, we graced the ears of Japan Town with our loud homage to The Darkness' "I Believe in a Thing Called Love" as we stumbled into the night.
author: Michelle C.

description: Sadly our experience tonight was disappointing. I have been here before a few times and loved the vibe, even celebrated my birthday here last year. Tonight I went with my boyfriend. We put in 6 songs around 8:30pm. By 10:15pm the KJ had played two of our songs and a million of everyone else's. I wouldn't have minded if it were crowded, but there were a total of 9 other people in the room, five of which sang multiple songs within that two hour stretch.  The bartender kindly refunded me the $8 for our songs because it's a work night and we had to go home. But I couldn't help but feel a bit put out. What's the deal? Is there something we should know in order to get our songs played or was this just a disorganized fluke?
author: Sarah T.

description:
La la la la laaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.... *glass breaks from the high pitched screeches*

When I think of a karaoke place, I think of those Korean owned places with individual rooms. There are endless booklets of English, Korean, Chinese and Japanese songs to choose from. And ALL the music videos have absolutely nothing to do with the song it's played with. 

Well, this is definitely NOT that kind of karaoke place.

This is an OPEN MIC karaoke place. Brave souls (or just really drunk people) can sign up to sing whatever song they want to the entire bar. I can see where the appeal is after you've hammered a few drinks. They may be loud and out of tune, but they're definitely having fun!

The bar itself is tiny and located inside the Kinokuniya building in Japantown. It's shoved in a little corner on the second level. If you have a hard time finding the place, just listen for the faint yet amplified screams of tone-deafness. 

It may be small, but it's a full bar inside! They even have soju and sake by the bottle! 

With a great selection of alcohol and the endless volunteers for karaoke, you can be entertained for hours! And if you can't stand the sound, take a breather in the hallway or down another drink. =P
author: Daisy T.

description: This is my favorite karaoke bar! In the past few years, I have frequented this tiny joint many times to ham it up onstage and purr into the mic. $2 per song, supportive crowd and nice staff. "Gangsta's Paradise" is MY JAM!!!
author: Suany W.

description:
Doing Karaoke and playing Rock Band are simply NOT the same thing!

I can now say that with first-hand knowledge, having finally visited Festa, my first-ever Karaoke bar.  

Does singing in the shower count by way of preparation?  Sure!  Will enough practice with Rock Band let you swagger up on stage and start belting them out like Bruno Mars?  It can't hurt (and for that matter, neither does a few rounds of Dutch Courage), but at the end of the day, there's absolutely nothing like singing in front of a live audience.

I always wanted try Karaoke, but I never did; then I joined Yelp.  Some Yelpers are terrified of Karaoke, some are passing fond of it, and some (like my friend Bobby L., who's "The Duke" of Festa) were born with a mike in their hand and a song in their heart.  The Elite of the Elite Yelpers all have one thing in common though - they'll try almost anything once!

At the tail-end of a Winter night earlier this year, a car-load of uber-Elites and I drove to this very-well hidden bar in Japantown.  Earlier that night, we had visited Little Star for some world-class deep-dish pizza http://www.yelp.com/biz/little-star-pizza-san-francisco#hrid:pakEuBxSaTX6zgJmErQ0GQ, then moved on to Cantina for some premium pre-Karaoke fortification.  I was feeling well-fed, well oil, and ready to wrestle 'gators when we arrived at the strip mall that contained Festa.

It's a good thing Bobby L., was driving - I never would have found the place in a 1000 years, even with the nav app in my Droid; well hidden doesn't begin to describe this bar!  Bobby could have found it in his sleep (and he probably has a few times) - displaying the ease of long practice, he guided us unerringly to the door.  We all walked in, and I took a look around.

The space is decidedly not big, about the size of an airport lounge; it has a small stage, with a twinkling city skyline backdrop, and a few tables huddled around it.  There's a bar against one wall.  The vibe is dive-bar intimate, and the crowd is friendly and supportive.  

Got any particular song in mind for your Karaoke debut?  They probably have it here!  There are 4 huge song books which are alphabetized by song title, artist, or language.  One of my friends started leafing through the book looking for a tune; I glanced over her shoulder, and saw "That'll Be The Day" by Buddy Holly - I remembered most of the words (heck, there are only about six of 'em) so that was my choice!


It's $2 per song, and no "official" DJ, so watch the prompter for your song - when it starts, you're on!  One by one and in pairs (duets are no problem here) my friends did the deed; then it was my turn.  I grabbed the mike, jumped up on stage, and sang for all I was worth...

While I probably could have scared The Dead with my caterwauling, I lived to tell the tale.  I got a real kick out of the Karaoke experience, and I'm sure I'll be trying it again in the not-to-distant future.

Festa is a great place for first-timers and veterans alike.  As this visit broke my Karaoke cherry, and I now fall into the latter category, I'll be back!
author: Glenn G.

description: I really want to like this place. I've been here a few times and for the most part have been happy. The drinks are tasty! But damn is there an attitude in the staff and a total lack of organization in the karaoke. What's the point in paying money to sing a song when the crazy lady behind the counter can't work the karaoke machine and plays requested songs out of order? You shouldn't have to wait 90 min to sing your song when people submitting songs after you get to sing before you. I'm a patient person but wow did you disappoint us.
author: Rad S.

description:
I love love loooove their martini cocktails!
I'd go there just for their saketini (w/premium sake)

Plus, you get to watch people singing while drinking. Free entertainment show :)

Welcoming bartenders, nice decor, and nice location. Definitely should check out.
author: Ginger K.

description:
This is def the best Karaoke place in the City!! I like how they are in obscurity in Japan town. This place is a little small but I like how it becomes like a private retreat. 
Their wine and cocktail is good, and I love their Lychee martini! 
The staff are welcome and friendly too.
author: Shintaro A.

description:
Was walking through J-Town and heard singing so we stopped by to check it out and ended up staying.  It was fun watching people do karoake - there were alot that were American Idol standard!!!  Its entertaining.

The place is well decorated, very cozy, and good ambience.

We would go again.
author: R M.

description:
4 Stars

+ Open Late
+ Large Selection of Songs
+ Good Service
+ Accepts Credit Cards
+ Happy Hour

+/- Open Mic haha

- No Private Rooms
- Small

My girlfriends and I found  this place after having dinner in Japantown a few weeks back. We originally walked in to get a few drinks and then realized it was a karaoke bar also! Great haha.

Drinks we ordered were: White Peach Bellini (White Peach and Sparkling Wine) $10 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTXkg5aU2rLJPBpsL3pmQ?select=1M8EjXJKyNQ973KvpVv7vQ, Pomegrandetini (Vodka, Pomegrande, and Lemon Juice)  $9  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTXkg5aU2rLJPBpsL3pmQ?select=noCVBoWMKghA0tMAEW56dw,Blue Tokyo (Vodka, Pineapple Juice, and Blue Curacao) $9 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTXkg5aU2rLJPBpsL3pmQ?select=_mKkiDS6joctXF1BP7hZlg and Ginger Lemon Drop  (Lemon Flavored Vodka, Lemon Juice, and Ginger Syrup) $9 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cFTXkg5aU2rLJPBpsL3pmQ?select=UGErfVOmHE_JMipWMcM0DA.

There weren't that many people in when we arrived so we were lucky enough to sing a few songs on stage. They have a pretty large selection of songs to choose from. English, Korean, Japanese, Chinese, you name it. Festa is open mic, therefore no private rooms and everyone gets up see you sing haha. Happy hour for free Karaoke starts from 7:30 pm and 9:00 pm.
author: Mona C.

description: Dropped in here on a whim after dinner in Japantown.  It's a small venue, very intimate.  Upon being seated, they ask you if you're going to be singing and hand over a song book.  The crowd is entertaining (mostly drunk) and the drinks somewhat original.  Unfortunately, because the crowd is so small, you end up seeing the same people onstage over and over again.  I did not have the courage (not drunk enough) to get up on stage....
author: Dexter L.

description:
I came this place for friend birthday
I really love this tiny karaoke bar.
So many selection of song and sound system was best !!!
author: Takashi Y.

description:
Japantown looked so beautiful last night with all of the trees in bloom.

I attended a private party  last night at Festa Karaoke Bar.  People sang their hearts out while others consumed cocktails and sang along from the sidelines and cheered for their fellow co-workers. 
It's a bit on the small side but yet so inviting, clean and friendly.
Good times were had by all.

Yeah!
author: Thomas D.

description:
As a previous Festa fan of four years, I'm truly disheartened by the fact that the bartenders hassled my party to buy drinks not even 10 minutes upon arrival.
Also hassled again when a new comer came in to check it out and just say hello to us- we were still working on a large sake. For some reason they SHORTENED happy hour to 1 hour (okkkk?). They advertise happy hour for 2 hours when in actuality it's one hour from 8-9pm and by 8:30pm they will charge $2/song for the simple reason that by the time your song gets played it would be past 9pm. Now no one is saying that $2/song is too much for karaoke but when you're friends are being told to, "not make a big deal about it" it really sends a tactless message to new patrons. I talk this place up all the time but truly- it seems to be turning into a sham of a nightlife establishment. It is so unfortunate to us veterans to know that a gem like Festa is going down hill from here. We ended up paying just as much for a private room at DoReMi karaoke studio down the street and had an epic time!
author: Sarah T.

description:
The drinks are strong with this one. Oh so very strong. Like, my head hurt for a solid day after a night of drinking/karaoking here. But boy was it fun at the time!  The downside, of course, is that the drinks are pricey. But you won't need many glasses of liquid courage to get on up and sing!
