The space is small, looking pretty airport loungey, but that's part of it's charm. Teeny stage, a few tables huddled around it. You'll most likely get pretty intimate with someone you don't know as it gets standing room only pretty quickly. Another bonus of the small space is that it doesn't take long for your song to come up since it doesn't fit very many.

The staff is super nice, the bartenders chatty and friendly. The biggest issue that I have is that you have to pay to sing! 2 bucks a song. Maybe I haven't been to enough karaoke only places and this is the norm but round Michigan the singin' is free (although I have been known to tip the karaoke master from time to time). So to have to pay was a little bit of a surprise. The staff runs the karaoke too, so it's not like they're paying someone separate. Hmm.

Otherwise it's a great place to enjoy a night out with friends, new and old. Karaoke is a fabulous ice breaker, dontcha know??
author: Annette J.

description: Ok. So let me say.. I have loved this place for years. I have had many great experiences and spent A TON OF MONEY here over the years.. They normally have a great staff that is super friendly and generally attract amazing guests.. But last night was EPICALLY bad terrible customer service and I have been in the service industry for over 10 years so I'm not just being a bitch.. The kj last night not only was rude and dismissive but he basically told our friend that if she came outside and had a cigarette with him then he "might play our songs". Are you seriously blackmailing us after we paid for songs to be played? Not only do you owe us our money back for purposely not playing our songs but you are never getting a single dollar from us again. and I'll be telling all our karaoke loving friends to never come here again.
author: Holly D.

description: Assholes. Expensive drinks. Terrible karaoke. They were terrible to us, and didn't let us sing. The KJ was awful. We paid him $10 to sing three songs... And he didn't put us on in three hours. We were at the front of the song line for two hours and the KJ kept telling us there were a lot of other people waiting. Try Encore instead.
author: Ian S.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars. The staff is friendly, the stage is intimate, and the Sapporo is served ice cold in chilled glasses, the way it should be. On top of that, there is an immense song selection (just be sure to look in multiple books) and it has carpet. Carpet? Are you kidding me? 

Where else will you find a clean, carpeted bar? 

Oh, and if you're lucky, you might see a local celebrity or two. This is the kind of place where you'll never run into anyone you know...unless they're on the up-and-up with secret karaoke bars in malls ;)
author: Michael F.

description:
Three dudes butchered my favorite Aerosmith song.
Cutting their throats would have been wrong.
This was going to be a short visit instead we stayed long.
I work the next morning why the hell did I come along.
F**k it i'm here now so help me belong.
Yes, i'm Filipino and don't sing...You stupid ding dong.
The size of this place is rather small and oblong.
With plenty of room for mahjongg or beer pong.
Bobby L sang so brave and so brawn.
He'd be the sh*tz if he performed in Hong Kong.
Thank you Badri, Hana, Bobby, and Chang (Chong).
You wore a short skirt what color was that thong?

LMAO!

I'm being stupid!   

Thank you Festa!   I'll be back!   Three stars for now!

And thank you Donna Y and Alex C for taking my drunk ass home back to San Jose!  =)
author: Walter P.

description:
--   "G R E E D Y"    --    

Festa is the "GOLD-DIGGER" of Karaoke bars.  

These people are not here to make friends or build community.  They are here to take your money.  Take note.  The karaoke is there to make those of us uncomfortable enough to purchase liquid courage.  It is a means to an end.  

I was so impassioned by Festa customer service - that I opened up a yelp account to write my first review.  Thanks Festa!  You are so inspiring.  

There have been two occasions where I have felt like Festa's staff took a big, sloppy dump on my face.  

1.)  Last year a group of my friends and I became addicted to karaoke.   We found Festa and instantly fell in love...we went every week for a month and a half, until we kept noticing that our table was not getting as much play as other tables.  We waited patiently in disbelief, one week after another.  We were in denial that they were playing favorites with other customers, colleagues and parties.  Finally one week, I tracked that bald KJ's movements and noticed that - yes- we were getting skipped.  F-ing shameless.  So after waiting an additional hour for any one of my party of 5 to go up, I went up to ask him where we were in the queue.  He shuffled around, searching only to reveal that he had put all 5 of our requests in a stack a foot away from the queue.  That night, we all got our money back and we left there promising never to return.  

This is what I think happened:  Being that we enjoyed karaokeing, we didn't need to calm our nerves with several drinks to get up on stage.  That night there was a birthday party ripe with karaoke newbees that had entered after us, which took priority over our requests.  This is what FESTA does.  

And we didn't go back for a year..

2.)  But we stupidly returned hoping that things had changed because we had loved Festa.   

Tonight was my second time back to Festa, and I was once again disappointed by their GREEDY soul-less ways.  

When I arrived at the bar I greeted my friends with hugs.  Unfortunately, I clumsily knocked over two full drinks when my bag swung forwards while leaning to greet a friend.  I immediately took the drinks to the bar and told the bartender.  She said yes.. and then made the drinks.  Then she asked for money.  And i said, "no it was an accident. They hadn't drunk any of it."  She kind of smirked and went to get the bald KJ and i retold the story to him.  He just stood there with a look of "what's your point?".  He charged me full price.  I tried to bargain for half price.  He offered only to take full price.  I bought my friends their drinks.  Ultimately, it was my fault.  

I owned a restaurant for 25 years, and accidents are part of the game.  Not at festa.
I am really frustrated.  And I am really mad, but any type of complaint doesn't seem to matter to them.  So since they don't care, hopefully you the reader will.  

I can't say it enough.  This is not how you treat your customers.  This is not how you run an establishment.  This is not how you treat people.  This is not how you treat regulars.  I would really like to see them go out of business.
author: Cin D.

description:
I remember stepping onto the stage,  my song of choice playing in the background while lyrics hit the screen... all the while with an obnoxiously mischievous look on my face.

FESTA IS AWESOME. It's my favorite place to go for karaoke, hands down! Great staff, great venue, all kinds of alcoholic brands to choose from including sake and soju and FUN!

I can't wait to go back again...
author: Tisha G.

description:
Festa turned out to be a swell place for a recent Sunday evening bday gathering. I see from their info that they'd like to charge you $100-$150 an hour to have a private party but on a Sunday you might just *cough* tell all your friends to show up and presto change-o you pretty much got the joint to yourselves especially if you've got a bunch of show-tune loving queens cuz the room is small and nobody is gonna want to hone in on your action. Or be near you and your Annie-Guys-n-Dolls-Seven-Brides-For-Seven-Brothers loving chums. Probably. But I'm not one to gossip and you didn't hear that from me. 

Minus a half-star for the sourpuss owner lady, (crack a smile, you're in the hospitality industry whether you like it or not) and minus another 1/2 star for the expensive drinks. Well at least I can tell you the least expensive glass of wine is $9 and that is one kind of wine the others are all much pricier. I imagine the cocktails are 'spensive too tho I did see some manual mint muddling going on so, you know, that drives the flavor and the price up.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I am probably one of the few Filipinos who can't sing. And not only that... I've always refused to sing. And how i wish i could!!!! 

You know how like when you're little and it's your grandma's birthday, and your mother would ask you to sing as a cutesy little present?? yeah. that scenario. My mom bribes me with Money just to sing. And it was an epic fail for her. I would still never ever Sing. (I played the piano instead and bowed- or recited a poem --and if i weren't cranky, danced to the beat of whatever in a ruffled skirt)

However. people change. Monica grew up and learned not to give a f*ck and what not. 

And coz Yelp friends are pushy (in a good way). and with them and karaoke, i am a pushover.

And at Festa... man...if i could only hog the mic for the whole night, I would. That mini stage...that gigantic, super updated songbook (They had Rolling in the Deep by Adele!!! - but that's for my next show ya guys -- when I'm not driving and i can drink and be drunk)... the awesome crowd who clap no matter how crazy one sings... the awesome bartenders....the clean restroom...the yummy cocktails....the comfy lounge chairs...

I love FESTA!!!!!
author: Monica H.

description:
I recently discovered Festa because my good friend and fellow Yelper Bobby L. just can't stop going here and introduced me to this little gem.

Located in Japantown in the Kinokuniya plaza, you'd not find this place easily if you didn't know what you were looking for!!  We usually come here weeknights so parking is usually never a problem :)

The place is small!  Really small!!!  Like, maybe, 50 people max and it will be really crowded with that many.  I'd put the comfortable capacity at about 30 people.

Which is perfect for most of us aspiring singers - get on stage without the stage fright of having to sing before an audience of 100 plus people :D

Fortified of course, by the awesome drinks from the bar :)

Songs are a very reasonable $2 each - for this, you get the privilege of getting on stage and belting out your favorite number to your heart's content!

I love the staff as well as the people who frequent this place.  You can tell several are repeat and regular customers which always speaks well of a place in my opinion.

I've been here twice and I know I will be back here many many more times.  It's a fun place filled with friendly people and people having a good time.  You can't go wrong with that recipe :)

~ 4 stars overall - there's no doubt in my mind I'll be back here.  Soon.

# 233
author: Badri N.

description:
******UPDATE*****
Was 2 stars.. Now 1, after essentially being called a liar.  
We had a few friends with us but if there are 2 glasses, 1 bottle, 1 bill and no wait staff there shouldn't be an auto gratuity, let alone 30%!!!!!
Bad business practices... 
Shame shame shame

****************

I think without my bad experience this would be 3 stars but experience shapes the review so 2 it is.  
I have been here before and had a great time.  We come, we karaoke, we drink, we laugh... Good times.  
The last time I came here it was a tad off.  Firstly, it was crowded, which is good for business but I think that's a sign that the *****DJs shouldn't sing in between people.*****  It takes up room for the patrons to sing... Not all of my friends got a chance to sing and I had a party of 6 and we were there for 3 hours. 
Secondly, the song selection is very weak and you can't hear yourself sing. No Roy Orbison? 
Thirdly, they start cleaning and kicking people out right at 1:30 am.  I hadn't finished my very expensive champagne and I was being ushered out!  They did try and be nice about having poor customer service saying  its the law and all this business about their license... I get it, but how is their licensing so different from any other joint in SF? Whatever..
Fourthly, this is the worst part... When they asked for my card to close my tab I did as I was told.  I bought one bottle of my favorite champagne for $80... They handed me the receipt to sign and said they added gratuity....??????????? I shared 1 bottle of champagne with my boyfriend!!!!! And they charged me 30% gratuity without asking!!!!!!!! 30% ?! ?!?!  Where do you get a number like that and why do you charge your patrons a gratuity?!! I filled our glasses each time... I shouldn't have to tip them $30 for walking a bottle 3 feet from the bar to my table, right?!?! And not have a say?!?! Of course when I try to dispute this I am ushered away and out,  not even able to finish my last glass.  Very bad service!!!
The readers of this review may wonder why there is 2 stars instead of 1..... Well, the fact they HAD my favorite champagne for sale at a karaoke joint is notable.  And I did have fun, more because of my friends and the other patrons but never the less... I will not come back!  There are way too many karaoke joints.. Ones that stay open till 4 am... That won't charge your party of two 30% gratuity .
author: blair k.

description:
This place is mainly great for karaoke & drinks.  Located at the end of the bridge between the Japantown malls, Festa is a small lounge with one bar and one karaoke stage, where most people hop on stage immediately or after a few drinks.

Overall, this place is great fun if you're into drinks and karaoke at night. Beware it's fairly small, where no more than 50 people can fit into this place. It's great to rent out for the night if you plan a birthday party!
author: Rob L.

description:
I would have never known this place if not for Tiffany N., who wrangled quite a few of us into this shopping mall for karaoke the other night. 

The tiny lounge is nothing much to look at (unless you like fake cityscapes gracing the walls), but the atmosphere was super friendly with everybody cheering and singing along. The bartender was one of the smiliest people who ever lived too. 

The bartenders do everything, so you pop them your song and two bucks (paying to sing is still pretty foreign to me, but I hear it's common in SF). Then, everyone stares at the screen after each song, braced to sprint up to the stage if they hear their song starting. This flustered me the first time since I didn't know (and missed like, three lines of my song before I made it up there). However, it's super efficient and it works well for them here!
author: Annie D.

description: I had so much fun here. It's small, chill and super friendly :)
author: Maryam M.

description: Cool place, lots of people coming in for one or 2 drinks and belting out a favorite tune. There is a stage with 2 mics so if you are shy, you can invite a friend to sing with you. Staff and bartenders are friendly. Even if you are not a good singer, the crowd appreciates the effort.
author: James W.

description:
If you figure one universal karaoke truism is that you don't always win at karaoke 'cause you can best belt out your favorites -- you win at karaoke on style points -- Festa might well prove the most apt metaphor for karaoke going. Tucked in the side pocket of a shopping mall in Japantown, I happened in here on the tip of some folks in the know for an evening of revelry and off-kilter crooning. 

The best part about Festa has to be that they don't announce your track - essentially, you have to pay attention -- and even then -- once your song starts, you have to haul ass to get up there in time for the beginning (or chorus, or coda, or whatever's left) of your song. This results in more than the requisite helping of hilarity, and at some point in the night a pack of my group camped out on stage for what no doubt seemed like four and a half years. Shorter to run, I gather. I love the cityscape backdrop, a tiny homage to the city surrounding (and cities everywhere, I gather). And like most knock offs in this place, packed with personality.
author: Kevin N.

description: This was one of the worse places!  Not only were the drinks extremely pricey,  they added the gratuity already. Even on individual checks. Which would be fine, if it was posted somewhere. Not sure how 3 beers and 3 shots cost $78.  And it was $2 per song. Again would be fine, but if I paid $2 I assume I get to sing the song by myself. I put in a song and there was another girl singing with me. I asked her why she sang with me.  She put in that song too. And she did and she paid $2 also.  Huge rip off of a place. I would have even this place one star if yelp would let me.
author: jean f.

description:
bathroom smelled like vomit but considering several individuals were over the limit on their libation intake made sense.. 

cute small venue 
owner was super cool 
TONS OF SONGS!
author: Vicky T.

description:
As we piled out of the taxi onto the sidewalk, we could hear the rest of our clan in joyful choruses: "Doooon't stop belieeevin'. Hold on to that feeel-ayayayin." We looked around for the entrance to Festa and merriment, and were like: How the hell do you get inside??

Luckily, the night's previous cocktails hadn't dimmed us enough to prevent discovering that the shopping mall entrance is the gateway to Festa. Up the staircase and round the corner, sure enough, we found the cubby-hole bar with a cityscape stage. The two bartenders were really nice, though there was the occasional drink mix-up. HIghballs seemed to run around $7. 

It's $2-per-song, and the books have everything from show tunes to goldie oldies to pop. We heard it all too... yes, even a rousing closing rendition of All That Jazz (cue: jazz hands).
author: Christina G.

description:
OK, so I understand that SF has more than its share of overpriced hole-in-the-walls. I can accept that. As Festa is located in Japantown I had the feeling that their financial strategy was to cater to out-of-towners wanting some karaoke action in the city.

That's all fine and good, what I cannot accept is charging $8 for Doritos and trying to double tip trickery.

If you are charging $8 for guacamole and chips, and you cannot serve Doritos. I'm pretty sure there's a law against it. Now, don't get me wrong. I love Doritos, but I love them when I pay 99 cents a bag, not a $8 dollars. The second offense was more serious though. 

When I went to pay the bill, my credit card had been charged a little more than I had expected. There was still the tipping space left blank so I assumed that maybe another item had been added to my bill. Low and behold, they had an 18% tip added because we were part of a group. The waitress explained this fact after the matter and pointed to a dark corner where there was 12-point font that explained their policy. OK, that's fine that that's your policy, what is not ok, is trying to get a double tip by presenting a receipt where there is a blank spot for the tipping section, and not mentioning that you've already received tip. 

Service was terrible anyway, which makes that 18% tip all the more ridiculous.
author: Daniel M.

description: Festa lounge staff are very friendly. Great drinks. Great decor. Awesome place to have fun with a group and karaoke!!
author: Felix T.

description:
This place is perfect for those of you who: think you hate karaoking (I know, can you believe those people exist??), have never gone karaoking or think you're "tired" of the sport.

I always ask myself why I don't come here more often. It has all the qualities of a great night: amazing bar and bartenders, easy (FREE) street parking after 8 pm, several hundred songs to choose from AND those classy Asian karaoke music videos playing in the background. There is absolutely nothing more I could ask for.

Festa is such a local joint. If someone snaps a picture of you singing in front of the fake skyline onstage or merrymaking with some pals in those obnoxious red swivel seats, only locals would know where you are. I love that about Festa. Plus the door guy is cute so don't forget to chop it up with him. 

I suggest coming in March during the SF Asian American International Film Fest to watch all of the festival staff unleash their inner Mariahs and Left Eyes (90s reference).
author: liz c.

description: When everything else closes up shop in the Kinokuniya building Festa is ready to party. My favorite part of this karaoke experience is that it's run by the bartenders. And they don't make any announcements about it being your turn to sing. They just keep the songs coming one after another and you have to listen for the one you submitted. When you hear it you run up to the stage and hope you make it to the mic before the words start. So if you like singing karaoke kamikaze-style in a place that's no bigger than most living rooms then get your vocal cords over to this spot stat.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Festa is always fun. The drinks are pricey and I've never been to a karaoke bar that charges patrons to sing, but I'd still consider this one of my favorite karaoke bars in the city for its intimate ambiance, friendly bartenders and extensive(-ly cheesy) song list.

BONUS: Last I went, a super-drunk Gavin Newsom-lookalike bought the entire bar a round of shots. Hope he comes back soon, too!
author: Sabrina V.

description:
Went here last minute for a quick drink around 1am right before last call on a Monday night. The place is small but very well decorated with a decent karaoke stage in the corner of the room. Drinks were strong (too strong for my gin and tonic. It tasted like straight gin but some may like that! ) and a little on the higher end price-wise (16 for the gin and tonic and a bud light in a bottle). 

The bartender was a bit rude, forgot our beer and acted put off that I reminded her about it. We only ended up staying a few minutes before she came to our table and told us that they would be closing early due to lack of customers (there were at least 11 other people in the place, which was a decent amount considering the size). We weren't even halfway done with our drinks before they were kicking us out, which was a huge turnoff. I've never been booted out of a bar before (well, only when I've been a bit naughty) and it made us uncomfortable, so we left without even finishing our drinks. Wish we had made it a block further and headed to the Boom Boom Room instead. We won't be returning.
author: Megan F.

description:
Seriously.  I'm a HUGE fan of the Mint.  It's my go-to place.  However, sometimes it's crowded.  Sometimes, the talent is pretty amazing.  Sometimes, it's a s***show.  Regardless, karaoke is in my blood and needs to sing.

I was having an early dinner at State Bird Provisions (see that review too!) with some periphery friends.  I'm just getting to know these folks and dinner was great for conversation only to discover a mutual love of the karaoke.  They mentioned that Festa is their fave place and right around the corner.

Epic.  The place was empty on a Saturday at 6:30.  We sang 9 songs before the next people came in.  When they did, so did everyone else, but that hour almost of just us and the drinks and the stage and the decor and everything.  It was pretty great.  

While I hate to yelp about this for fear of other folks finding it, I still think you need to experience it.  I'm likely not due for another karaoke adventure until July, so have at it until then and maybe you'll hear my mean "Careless Whisper" like a siren song luring you there.
author: Andy S.

description:
I went here with a friend one Tuesday evening and we had a really great time singing. The joint is small and intimate, so it feels like you're singing to a contingent of friends. Beware if you show up on a Saturday night it's worse than going to the DMV... there's a crowd spilling out the door.

I found the cheese plate to be a waste of money. If you typically have cheese plates at restaurants, you'll be sorely disappointed with what Festa is offering... a couple of blah American cheeses and some soda crackers? Hmpf.

Since I haven't lived here for very long, I've not had a chance to visit many karaoke bars in the city. However, I find it mildly offensive that they charge $2 per song to sing. When I'm racking up a hefty tab from drinking their $10 cocktails all night, I expect the karaoke to be gratis. But maybe that's a San Francisco thing. The staff is friendly and the crowd is fun, but I won't be returning.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Last night was the first time I've been to Festa for karaoke, and I've had far better.

Firstly, they charge $2 a song after 9pm. If I'm there buying $9 whiskey cokes, I think my songs should be free. I promise I'll keep drinking if you let me keep singing.

The cost of the songs also dramatically changed our group's dynamic. People who normally sing a ton sang far less, and you had to be much more serious about your song choices, because no one wanted to wait in line and then pay $2 for something just for fun. It killed the group's spontaneity.

The staff was also far from friendly. They weren't very accommodating, no smiles, nothing. They did not seem to be enjoying their job.

The crowd towards the end of the night also got douchier. There were a bunch of guys at the bar who weren't there to sing, but were yelling out "this song sucks!" to people. It killed the vibe.

The only redeeming factor of Festa is that the karaoke sound system is decent.

So if you don't mind expensive drinks, paying for your songs, unfriendly staff, and douchy patrons heckling you, Festa is alright.

Overall, I'd recommend Pandora. They have private rooms and a main stage area for public singing, you can easily get to know your bartenders on a first name basis, people there are really friendly, and songs are free all night. I'll be recommending Pandora over Festa for the group karaoke next week.
author: Ryan S.

description:
This place is a terrible rip-off. A one (very overpriced) drink minimum AND karaoke charged by the song? Come on guys, choose one or the other.

So my group comes in, gives them money for a few songs, and sits down. So they charge per song and don't even have a DJ to call names? You have to pay attention to the screen or you might miss your song. Whatever.

Usually when there's a minimum someone comes up to you and asks for your order right away, but we weren't approached for about 30 minutes. When they did, they asked if we ordered a drink and that they found a whiskey bottle near our table. They falsely accused us of sneaking it in, and told us that if we didn't order drinks that we'd have to leave - never mind the fact that we already put in money for karaoke and were still waiting for one more song. Thankfully the song came up, I belted the tune, and we promptly left.

Rude staff, rude owner, overpriced drinks, karaoke charged by the song. I am never coming back.
author: James B.

description:
I used to go to the Mint until we discovered Festa. It's my new favorite kareoke bar in SF for the following reasons:

- you can be a terrible singer, yet it's ok. this bar is not as showy or competitive as The Mint. That also means you get a lot of bad singers, but that is part of the fun.
- drinks are very good. or so my friends say. I always drink tequila shots so can't speak much about the fancy cocktails they serve
- yes, you have to pay for a song. but you can sing many songs during the evening Vs the 1-2 songs you get to sing at the mint
- It's small and cozy, yet you can go there with a large group. Everytime we go, we have a nice place to park our group w/o much hassle. 
- song selection gets better with every visit. 

Love this bar. Was there on my bday. Oh, and did I mention that everytime we leave something behind (ie, coats and phones) it never goes missing. I left my phone behind last sat and they even called me to let me know they had it. How nice is that.
author: Larissa A.

description:
I crashed a birthday party at Festa after a Yelp Elite event on a Wednesday night. 

Funny story: There's only one bathroom here. I was waiting for it, when the birthday boy sat down to wait, too. Knowing that he was the birthday boy, I introduced myself and said he could go first unless he was going to pee all over the seat. He said he could hold it, and shoved me toward the bathroom. When I came out, he was on the stage singing "Poison" by Bell Biv DeVoe with his friend. 

(which is a great transition to my next thought)

My thoughts on public karaoke in the words of Bell Biv DeVoe: 

If I were you I'd take precautionnnn...

before doing karaoke with Yelpers, because the odds are, one of them has it recorded on their camera. 

And if you slight one of them, ooooh, that might surface on the Internet. 

But then again, my threshold for public humiliation might be really low, so what do I know?
author: Amy D.

description:
I dig karaoke...a lot!!!  But I had a very bad experience coming here.

So I came here with good friends of mine.  The place has good decor no doubt but $2 a song?  Come on now, really?  I wanted to have spent that money on drinks instead.  And there was a time where they were playing songs of people who requested after us and turns out they had put my paper at the bottom by mistake.

We had a little disagreement with some drunk girls who tried to steal our stage during our turn.  No respect at all.  If that wasn't irritating enough, the management didn't do anything about it.  Okay, one of my friends was a regular here.   And he's been bringing 4 or so people with him each time.  Where's the pay off for loyalty?  Apparently, they didn't care.

We left that place annoyed.  Too bad Festa, you lost one good customer, oh wait, make that 10 and some customers.
author: Pam S.

description: You are visiting the city, you have to go to this little karaoke. People are awsow there, I spend only one night in San Francisco and my friends from there, took me out and it was amasing, GO THERE OF YOU CAN !! Fun night
author: Eloise C.

description:
The five star rating still stands.  No question.  

That said, I am dismayed by the ingratitude and cheapness regularly demonstrated by a lot of the hipster patrons who would drunkenly dispute a tab they festively racked up buying rounds of shots for their friends, and after having their itemized bill thoroughly run down for them, still leave a 5 percent tip for the bartenders who have to put up with a lot of pushy customers who bitch about their songs not being played two minutes after they put in their request.  I've taken for granted the fun derived from people watching.

The bartenders make the bar.  Not the hoards of tools singing their crap cornier than my leavings after eating a Chipotle burrito.
author: Eric P.

description: I LOVE Festa! The people here are so nice. It's in Japantown (and I love Japantown). Oh, and the ambiance is just the best among karaoke bars - I love the city lights and stars along the walls and that you can look out the window over the street. The music selection is good, too. I almost always find the songs I want to sing. :)
author: Jason B.

description:
$2.00 per kareoke song.....

Like other reviews, I"m not sure how I feel about paying to sing kareoke.  I'm already there buying drinks.  I guess I"m spoiled by the other kareoke bars  I"ve been to where you don't pay to sing.  But the two bartenders were really nice and even chatted with us a bit at the bar.  No drink specials when we were there Sat night, at least none that I saw or heard of.

This place is located in the Kinokuniya plaza.  We stayed at the kabuki next door, but if you need parking there's a lot in this plaza down below.  You can easily miss it if you're not looking out for it.   It's a really small spot with no actual stage.   You could basically sing a song from your table. There's some chairs and tables and maybe 8 stools at the bar.   I guess this would be great if the whole room is you and your friends, otherwise get ready to share Festa with say 20 of your closest strangers.
author: Bernadette M.

description:
YES. 

A karaoke place that has The Darkness? Green Day? Red Hot? Nirvana?

All the songs I've ever wanted to sing at a Karaoke bar. Not that I'm raggin' on asian tunes or 80's classic (I did a beautiful job on Mike's "Rock with you" before my voice gave out to the high notes only he can master!) but it's really really nice that they included a lot of the....unusual fare. That right there was 4 stars. 

The get up and go rotation of songs is the fun part I think: getting up in front of your friends and a bunch of strangers is nerve racking (plus there are some pro frequenters too! Some dude was killin' it on stevie wonder!) but its great fun just lettin' loose. I think people will have a better time if you're not trying so hard you know? You have a good time, everyone has a good time. Words to the wise indeed. 

I couldn't blame em for the rest: the major wait times, the fairly weak cocktails: they're just they way they are. Man that long island was some turrrable business though. Glad I only had a beer. Gotta protect the voice to swoon the ladies! hahaha. 

Its 2 bucks a song and the drinks are a bit pricey (6 for a bottle of saporro? meh...) but pro tip: get your song list in order. If you want to sing 10 songs, write down 10 songs. If you decide mid way through, tough luck if you got a pretty nice crowd building up. Stake your claim and just relax for the rest of the night! That's what I'm doin' next time.
author: Dzu N.

description:
If you are ever looking to hang with Japanese businessmen, this is the place to be. During my time in Japan, I learned that Karaoke, and drinking (particularly whiskey) were key components of the post-work routine for Japanese professionals. It's not wonder that you can often find Japanese tourists/businessmen hanging around here in Festa, drinking sake, and belting out american and japanese ballads.

The drinks here are excellent. While on the girly side, the Peach Bellini and the Sparkling Sake were great. Of course, I didn't order either--I wrapped my manly paws around chivas in a whiskey tumbler. But perhaps my companion ordered some and was overly gracious in her sharing.
author: Andrew H.

description: Drinks are expensive but the atmosphere was great. I'll def come back to sing and laugh. However, the space is small and you could feel a little cramped inside if you're uncomfortable with small spaces. But i think that's part of the intimacy and attraction of this place.
author: Jay W.

description:
If after a big Italian meal and multiple bottles of Prosecco someone suggests it's time to pop your karaoke cherry, say 'yes'. If en route to a mysterious karaoke bar someone tells you it's in a Japanese strip mall, say 'bring it on'. If entering the mysterious karaoke bar it ends up looking like an airport watering hole in Tulsa mixed with a stage borrowed from bad nineties stand up, say 'hell yes'. If after a few songs you realize that you've unknowingly crashed somebody else's office party, say 'I can rock these bitches under the table.'

Pay particularly close attention to the completely unrelated b-roll footage that rolls behind the lyrics - it ranged from Demi Moore headshots during Total Eclipse of the Heart to water treatment plants during the Backstreet Boys. Or maybe it wasn't unrelated...

Staff were incredibly friendly which is great since the bartenders themselves are the ones managing the song order and making sure larger groups have enough microphones. That said, there were a couple of downsides in the overpriced drinks, the fact that performer names aren't announced so you need to bumrush the stage when you hear your song, multiple appearances of Baby Got Back, and the fact that you're pretty much guaranteed a hangover.
author: Ben B.

description: Festa's is my favorite place to sing karaoke in San Francisco. Good atmosphere with a good sound system for singing, very friendly people and wait staff, and good drinks. A nice size place for karaoke also. Everyone has a god time here. A friend took me here years ago, and I still come to Festa's when I am in San Francisco.
author: John C.

description:
When I rolled up to Festa late on a Tuesday night and the entire shopping mall was deserted less a tiny bar full of people jammin' karaoke, I had no idea what type of fun awaited me.

I'm no stranger to a karaoke night. I have hit many a bar in search of a mike and some cheesy 80's music. But this one is different. It's tiny and there's no formal announcement when it's your song. You just hear the music and take the stage. It was fantastic. 

Drinks were pouring. Ice cold beer and tasty cocktails all around. And there may have been a shot or two once or twice. All great and pretty easy on the wallet. 

Recommend!
author: Kay T.

description:
SELECTION OF SONGS GETS 5 STARS!!!! Never in my life have I seen such a huge selection of Crystal Kay and Amuro Namie jams to sing. I was in heaven!

When I first got there, it was about 8 or so so not many people were there yet. I had a saketini. It was OK. (After trying my 3rd saketini at this bar, I'm beginning to realize I'm not a fan of the saketini. Lol.) Luckily it was free bc some old Japanese dude bought it for me. Hooray!

Since there weren't alot of people in the beginning, there were many opportunities to sing. Everyone was really friendly and welcoming. I just got there that day and already I felt like I was at home. Is this what they talk about when they say friendly people live in San Francisco?

Maybe... but singing here does not come free.

Well, before I left, I was told to pay $2 PER SONG and the guy scribbled a bill on a scratch sheet of paper. I've been to so many karaoke places and never did I have to pay per song. I thought he was joking, laughed it off, and left the bar. Well, next thing you know, the guy follows me and shows up OUTSIDE of the bar still asking me to pay for the 5 songs I sang. He tells me I owe him $10 and his manager was going to get mad at him if he didn't pay for those 5 songs. I still think he was joking. He insisted he wasn't so I followed him to the bar so he could show me proof. O man o man. He wasn't joking!! In fine print, it says "$2 per song." 

Ironically, I come in here later on to show this place to some random people who were wanting to karaoke. And apparently this happens alot. Another confused customer was listening to another worker from this bar explain about the $2 per song bill. Lol. 

I was in Kinokuniya on Monday and I could hear people jamming it out here through the walls. Lol. I guess they are open everynight.

So, in short, I REALLY REALLY REALLY REALLY like this place for their very friendly atmosphere, extensive song collection listed by artist, and being open everynight. But I don't like it for their $2 per song deal.
author: Julie A.

description:
BRING YOUR CAPE AND BOOTS. 

This is an old school karaoke bar. You'll see the hot middle aged Japanese women tending bar and the creepy old white guys who seem nice enough but are just a little too touchy by Asian standards. Good song selection and plenty of high kick room on stage. Make a fool of yourself in front of others, there's no feeling quite like it.
author: Dominic C.

description:
What fun!  This attractive little hideaway in SF's Japantown is a jewel.  Knowledgeable bartenders create your drink of choice and go ahead - take a stab at karaoke!
The lists of songs are huge and you are sure to find one you like.
Great place to meet friends and have a lively evening. You'll love it.
author: Nel S.

description:
WOW, I really wish Yelp had a negative star feature. 

The Staff and Owner are RACISTS and LGBT crowd haters, while also being out right thieves. 

FESTA is a small, odd & yet interestingly conceptual place. 

WHEN you can get the staff to bother paying attention to you and get your drink order which they are supposed to do, they take their time like we are serving them...They need to remember the customer is the person being served (not them), wait staff is supposed to serve their customers in a polite, warm and inviting way so customers will return, insuring wait staff income to live. 

A date introduced this place to me in November of 2008. They were rude from the first second we walked in....it took forever to get a drink and them they were wrong every time we order another round. 

Paying eight bucks a glass for a wine that I would not serve mass murders is a crime. Ever changing pricing is illegal and a crime here. 

The wait staff was suspicious of my date and I at first, but they were making too much fun and saying disgustingly ignorant remarks about a table of women that they concluded were lesbians. When they when they realized we were gay became out right offensive. They talked about us, not realizing that between the two of us we understood fag comments in the several languages they tried to hide their barbaric attitudes. 

All night long PEOPLE complained about not getting to sing their songs. That is because we found out later after some people left not getting their requests is because if you are not a friend of the owners then you are screwed. They charge $2.00 for the song request, then keep the money after not playing them and they use the money to buy drinks later. If they were an intelligent customer serve oriented business they could just keep a simple list in order to request songs and avoid the whole thing, but no they deliberately piss off paying customers. 

If your WHITE in this bar, forget it, the owner and staff are going to make you pay for whatever transgression every white person has ever done to anyone in the history of the planet. And God forbid you are Asian, but not Japanese, you are even more screwed. 

I think everyone on Yelp should call the Mayor's Office, Police Dept and the Human Rights Commission and complain about illegal business practice, racism and hate crimes toward the LGBT community. Then we could form a class action suit and sue their asses out of business. 

And for the Japan Town business community, I feel sorry because this place does not reflect the good people that run professional businesses in anyway....it just hurts that community. 

They should change the name to FESTER, because that is what it does and one day someone will lance the boil of that Festering place supposed there to serve people.
author: T.J. L.

description:
I'm reviewing this place as a place for a private Karaoke Event.

So I've had two friend's birthdays where they decided to Karaoke. One was at a regular Karaoke place and one was here. My friend rented out the entire room for some unknown amount of money. But it was worth it.

Unlike the regular asian places where there's no central point of look at everyone just looks at the screen, this is more how I thought karaoke should be. With one or two people singing the actual song in front and being able to put on a real performance. 

The alcohol was decent and regularly priced, the service was excellent, and they had giant song books with pretty much every song known to man. There are of course exceptions (really no OffSpring?), but whatever. They also have far more modern stuff, this is the only place I've seen Lady Gaga in. They even had the latest Katy Perry song (the one that just came out from the date of this review). 

One weird thing was that the books titles were mixed up. The one that was sorted by artist was sorted by title, the one by title was actually by artist. UPDATE: This was fixed, apparently the owner reads Yelp reviews, if only there was 6 stars?
author: Rohan D.

description:
My new favorite local drinking place...
Of course, since it is close to home that is a plus.  The bartenders are nice... drinks and pours are not as heavy as I would like, but everything in moderation right?   

I do not sing, so I just sit at the bar, and talk to whoever my drinking buddy is that evening.  Since I do not know Japanese, if they sing badly or good in Japanese, I wouldn't be able to tell.  But I can tell if people sing badly in English.  And let me tell you... it can get pretty bad.  Just imagine drinking so much you are compelled to pay the $2 surcharge to sing a song.  Well sometimes it ain't pretty.  I'm not passing any judgment because as long as they are having a good time, it's cool with me.  Who knows, maybe one evening I will get piss drunk and sing, "Baby one more time" by Britney
author: Debbie N.

description:
After reading Jim's tomb below (pretty comprehensive stuff there!) I am not sure what else I can bring to the party. But I will say this much - I love karaoke, mostly consisting of the secret-room-where-no-one-but-close-friends-and-loved-ones-can-see-me-make-a-fool-of-myself kind, but Festa opened my eyes to what the make-a-fool-of-yourself-in-front-of-everyone thing is all about. The drinks may be pricey (I just glommed onto someone else's big beer bottle orders) but the atmosphere totally makes it worth the cost. I even sang along to one of the few Japanese pop songs I can wrangle. I love Namie Amuro!
Go. Have fun. Be a fool.
author: Holly C.

description:
I have never reviewed an establishment for yelp but I feel compelled to after last night. 

I went there with a few friends for a quick drink and some entertainment. When the server came over, I ordered a shot of whiskey and a coke chaser.... When the bill came, I was charged $9 for the shot and $5 for the coke chaser. That makes a $14 whiskey and coke! I asked the server if something was wrong and he looked at me like I was crazy... Never going there again.
author: None O.

description:
Festa rocks my world.

This is the place I come to a few times a month to knock a few drinks back and sing my heart out. After a long week at work there isn't a better way to unwind and decompress. 

The intimate, friendly atmosphere is what makes this place tops. The crowd here is fun and supportive so even if you're a little scared to sing up on stage alone, everyone else will be singing along with you anyway. :) It's also nice to come to a karaoke bar where you don't have to deal with rude karaoke DJ's or wait around for 3 hours to never hear your song come on. Plus, their pomegranate martinis are yummy and potent.

Some people are complaining about the $2/song fee. If you're complaining about spending $2 then you should head over to your nearest seedy dive bar instead of coming to a place with a nice ambiance.
author: Athena E.

description:
This is my best friend's favorite bar. I was rather apprehensive because I really don't like singing in a roomful of strangers. I prefer doing karaoke in a private room with only friends and/or family present. However, this past New Year's Day, after a few drinks, I conquered my shyness and belted out a few tunes on the stage. I was surprised that I wasn't more freaked out. In fact, I had a damn good time. 

This bar is quite cozy and intimate, with several tables and chairs set up all over the room. The stage is small with a rather cheesy cityscape backdrop. A TV screen in front of the stage displays song lyrics. The song selection was pretty good - a fair number Western, Japanese, and even Korean tunes. 

This Japantown spot is Japanese-owned and bartended. The bartenders are very cool and the atmosphere is lively and fun. The crowd is an eclectic mix of older and younger folks, mostly Asian and Caucasian. 

While I still prefer the private karoake room, I would definitely come out to Festa again. And if my friend has her way, it will undoubtedly be soon!
author: Jenny K.

description: Did i miss the memo that karaoke is charged by the SONG?? what the hell?? the drinks  were supremely overpriced and the staff was a little snobby. i guess it used to be a little lower key coming to Festa, but unless you're in to drop a hundred dollar bar tab, skip it and go elsewhere
author: Carolina S.

description: Music, booze & fun.  Thumbs up!  Atsuko knows how to concoct my poison.  I love this place.
author: Kit P.

description:
I cannot say that this place is the worst establishment that I've ever been to however it's close to it. 

I just went here tonight.  The place is really small and there is about 6 tables total in addition to the 6 or 8 stools at the bar area.  There were two-three bartenders working.

I arrived there at 10PM to meet with my party of seven people and it was really mellow and a little bit dead.  Around 10:30PM, people started to sing and once they started, the ball started to roll.

I've never done public karaoke before, so I ordered some Lychee Martini's to loosen me up :)  It was quite tasty and the bartenders were very fast in delivery and attentive as well; they came around a few times to check on each table.  The negative is each drink cost $9.00.

There was a huge binder of songs, which was pretty cool --oldies to current pop/rock.  

I thought I'd actually be much more nervous on stage but I wasn't.  You come here expecting that people do not sing very well --it's not American Idol.  The people that I've met and witnessed tonight have all been really cool and friendly --very supportive and interactive with you when you are stumbling upon lost words.  I was actually singing a song that I have never heard and I got so much support from the crowd :)  They are very encouraging but in a non-pressuring kind of way --good folks. 

Things were good until the owner started to move people around.  My group and I were asked to scoot in and squeeze together so that another group of people can sit down. This also happened to another table that was nearby us; there was an empty table where no one was sitting and the owner of the establishment had asked them to move from one table to the one where no one was sitting.  In addition to that, she took my drink away without asking if I was done with it.  

Keep in mind that we've been there for over an hour or two and we were drinking and singing actively on stage.  I thought what she did was extremely rude --the rest of my party agreed so we left.

To make matters worse, we went to close our bill and found out that they had charged us for three additional drinks when we paid for them already in cash.  We tried resolving the issue by speaking to them and they refused to take the amount off. 

Our night turned sour very quickly -- we will definitely never come back to this place again.

Also, I saw the cheese plate from another table and I definitely would not recommend ordering that.  It was literally slices of over priced cheddar or cheap looking cheese.  I am not impressed at all.
author: Brenda T.

description:
I have to agree with Megan C.

The scene is really cool in appearance here... but don't be fooled!  First, the cokes were $5.  Seriously.  The guy told me, "it's on the menu," but it wasn't.  Then he said "you should have asked what the price was before ordering it... what did you expect it would cost?"  This was not a supersize coke.  It was in a whiskey-type glass.  

OK, whatever.  The KJ was totally discriminatory towards our table.  Some people, even those who came after us, sang four songs to our one.  

I really like the scene, but the super rude staff and ridiculous mark-ups on drinks will keep me away... there are much better places in the city!
author: E M.

description:
I feel very bad for T.J. down below who had a really bad experience here, because when I've gone, I've felt like Festa has a really positive, welcoming atmosphere. 
Nice hostesses and bartenders, and I just like the idea of being able to pay per song and just hang out for a few hours without having to pay a "per hour" fee like private karaoke rooms. 

Pretty good drinks too. My favorite so far has been the lychee cocktail. The Blue Tokyo is a little too strong for me, and the saketini is.. interesting. If you like sake, you'll probably like it. 

There is a wide range of singers/people that come here. You don't have to be the "karaoke-type" to enjoy it. You seem to get them all here-- Japanophiles singing in Japanese, Asian people, non-Asian people, good singers, amazing singers, not so good singers, older Korean lady belting out cheesy Korean songs. Good oldies seem to dominate the list of requested songs.  

The downside: 
Here are some reasons why I knocked off 2 stars.
- The price of the drinks. I know a cocktail for $9-10 isn't ridiculous, but... it gets old after a couple of drinks, and I wish they had more of a variety on their menu. They basically have expensive cocktails, cheaper beer ($5-10), and very expensive wine. 

- the selection of the songs. Ya, they have Japanese and Korean songs, and a great selection of older songs, but their newest page (as of March) was songs from January 2010, and even then, they didn't have any Gaga! This complaint is really only half-serious, but how could you not have any Gaga? Even just a few from her first album?? Maybe they don't wanna hear it every night. 

- the wait-time for your requested songs. Our group waited about 30 minutes for one song, and about an hour for our second song, even though we requested them within one minute of each other. You definitely have to come in, sit down, request a song first, and then buy drinks, enjoy yourselves, etc. If you hold off too long to request a song, your wait time will just get longer and longer. Definitely a different kind of karaoke experience for me, because I'm used to private rooms. Just keep in mind that you can't just decide at the last minute you wanna sing something--
author: Saori E.

description:
Randomly walking around, after visiting Harry's Bar up Fillmore, the peeps and I were looking for something to do in the area.  We were walking down Post, when we heard some noise 'singing' upstairs in the Kinokuniya building.  We decided to check it out, not knowing what to expect.  Alas, a karaoke bar! We decided to stay. The crowd was young, and the mood was right. We ordered the best Sapporo's I've ever had, nice and cold in a frozen glass. Then some pro decided to bust out some Whitney Houston on the karaoke, and then they closed. Didn't realize it was getting late.

Anyway, this place was great, cozy, and fun. Didn't sing, but we were just there looking for some entertainment over drinks.
author: Lyndon M.

description: Thanksgiving night worst customer service ever. Great customers celebrating a birthday party but the guy in charge of songs apparently thinks American idol missed him on their great search for talent. He's an arrogant "kj" who thinks he's going to be the next great thing and has no respect for his customers at Festa. Your loss.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
I am a fan of karaoke bars and will saunter up to the microphone in a dive bar or a classy joint.  I was excited when I walked into Festa to see such a nice atmosphere and hear an older gentleman singing some Sinatra. I thought then that I was in for a good night, but boy was I wrong.  I don't even know where to begin.

I went on a Friday not expecting to get a million songs in, but hoping for at least 1 or 2.  I understand how the queuing process generally works at karaoke bars, so I had no problem putting in a couple song requests, having a couple drinks, taking in the other performances, and waiting. The cost per song here is $2, which is fine by me if that means less people will be inundating the KJ with drunken song requests.  

I watched as the same people came up to the stage over and over, as many as 4 times, before anyone in my party even got a single song in.  It was not a question of the other people getting to the bar before us- I saw them come in at least 20 minutes after I arrived at Festa.

As the night passed, I realized that some of the repeat singers were friends of the owner.  They were seated at a table that we were told was reserved for a large party.  When the party came in, I was asked to move from my non-reserved table to make up for the space that the friends were taking at the table that had been reserved.

If the table moving experience wasn't enough of an annoyance, my song NEVER came up.  After 90 minutes had passed, I inquired about my song and saw it about 3 songs back in the queue atop a large stack of my groups requests (some of which had been paid for in cash in advance at the bar).  30 minutes later my song still didn't come up.  When I asked about it this time, hoping for a real explanation, the KJ said that it was the way the line worked and assured me it was all fair, and that my song was still 5 songs away.  So after 2 hours of patiently waiting, cheering on other singers, and buying drinks, I told the KJ to remove all my songs requests.

When I went to close out my tab, I was charged an 18% automatic gratuity for being a part of a group of 6 or more people.  Granted, there were 6 of us, but we were never served as a group, and none of the others were charged this gratuity.  It seemed to have been made up on the spot.  And after 2 hours of being ignored, I was in no mood to leave a tip at all, none the less an 18% tip.

The entire night my group got 3 songs in TOTAL while EACH REGULAR got AT LEAST 2 songs in, and as many as 4.

It really is a shame, I was ready to give up on other karaoke spots in favor of the warm ambiance of Festa.  But after being treated as I was, I can't say that I will ever go back.  

Only go here if you are a friend of the owner.  Don't go in groups of 6, don't make friends with another table so they think you are a group of 6.  But better still, just go somewhere else where you won't be treated like shit.
author: Megan C.

description: Fairly good music selection.  Great ambiance.  Love the staff.  Horrible martinis that have too much vermouth --- other drink options are good.  Will come back often.
author: Joe N.

description:
Are you the type of person who has no shame? Do you sing in the shower? Do you think you can carry a tune even if your friends say you can't? If you answered yes to all of the above, then you are just what Festa is looking for on a nightly basis. Located in the heart of Japan Town, this karaoke bar is just what you need to prove your friends wrong. Rock the mic without shame and I assure you, the crowd will be behind you 100 percent! 

I'm more accustomed to private room style karaoke where the only people who can witness your shamelessness are the people in your group (usually your "so-called" friends). This type of karaoke should be more intimidating but once you realize that the people that go up on stage ahead of you don't have any qualms about looking like complete idiots, your confidence will take a significant spike. 

It's funny how cheesy 80's and 90's songs bring everyone together. At one point, I got up there and rocked "Semi Charmed Kind Of Life" with some drunk sot who was up there butchering the song. Everyone in there, regardless of which group they belong to, always cheers you on and sings along no matter how off key you are. I guess that's why it's always a good idea to pair karaoke with alcohol. Can you imagine how we must sound without it?

Good times!

4.4 stars
author: Angelo B.

description:
Hands down the worst customer service I've ever had at a bar in San Francisco.  I came in with a large group but had no intention of ordering anything even though other people were.  My friend and I asked for tap water, and the waitress brought us bottled water that she wanted us to pay for.  We refused it and politely clarified that we wanted tap water.  She came back with two Sapporos.  What?? Fine. We'll take the Sapporos, which she said (and the menu said) were $6 each.  (Reading the reviews I now realize there is a drink minimum so maybe that's why she did this, although that was not made clear to me).  I gave her my credit card, and she came back with a bill for $15.50.  $15.50?!  When I challenged it, she said I had to pay 18% gratuity because I was sitting with a large group.  But I was ordering as a party of 2!! I wasn't paying for everyone's drinks!  And even so, $12 plus 18% gratuity is $14.16, not $15.50.  I obviously refused to pay this.  Then she had the gall to come back with a $13 check, which was STILL ripping me off (since drinks aren't supposed to be taxed in a non-restaurant, and there's no way sales tax on two drinks is an even $1), but I was too fed up to protest more.

Absolutely appalling. On top of all this, they charge $2 per song and have a pretty lame selection of music.  This place does not deserve your business.
author: Mari S.

description: this place was way smaller than i anticipated!  i came for a bday party last wknd and had a lot of fun!  there are a lot of song choices, but they are a bit difficult to find in the huge books.  each song costs $2 to sing, so it makes for a pretty cheap evening.
author: Helen T.

description: Ended up here a few months ago to meet up with friends who love this place, and I had a blast! Small, intimate but nice lounge (not gritty/divey), and because it's small it's more casual and fun, rather than feature some intimidating stage. Full bar plus lychee cocktails. I would've had fun just watching everyone and hanging at my table, but yes, we ended up singing. It felt like our own party after a certain point, with one guy from our group singing Sinatra and a bunch of us dancing up front. Great neighborhood spot if you can find it (it's just inside the Japantown mall).
author: Sandra P.

description: So much fun!  This is a perfectly-designed Karaoke lounge.  The atmosphere is friendly and the stage is optimally set up for full enjoyment of performances.  (That said, poor performances and song choices are somewhat of an issue, but I can't deduct stars for the clientele...)  I would come back every week just to sing my guts out and watch others do the same!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Possibly the best karaoke bar in SF even though it's fairly unknown. Festa is all about the music. I saw some fantastic singers here. They were so good that I was embarrassed to go onstage. Eventually I worked up the courage to bust out a 10 minute performance of Rapper's Delight -- a song I haven't seen elsewhere. 

The song selection at Festa is huge and bigger than any other place in SF I've been to. The friendly bartender kept the hot sake coming and I had a great time here.
author: Aaron V.

description:
i'm surprised at all the rave reviews for this place.

the group i was with arrived to festa around 9:30pm or so.  the five of us camped out in the booth in the corner.  it was my first time.  man, what a small place... not in a bad way, just intimate and i never would have known this place existed.  i don't think it's divey at all like some of the other reviews said.  i've done divey and festa is not divey.  you can't call a place that charged $9 for a gin and tonic a dive bar.

speaking of $9 gin and tonics, i order a tanqueray and tonic and it was $9 and on my next drink i thought to specify that i wanted their well gin thinking it would be at least a few bucks cheaper... nope, $9.  i had three drinks and i could have taken that $30 and purchased myself a bottle of gin, tonic and limes and gotten myself sloppy drunk.

ANYWAYS...

i'm a huge fan of karaoke and was surprised to learn that you have to pay $2 to sing.  uh, come again?  and the guy who manages the karaoke thing told my friends that the song order is not done by who gets their songs in first but instead by table to limit repeats or something.  yeah, well, what we didn't know is that you can slip the karaoke guy some extra money to get your song bumped up to the top of the list.  we learned this when someone in our group had to wait like 45 minutes for their song.

seems like it could be a fun place... but over-charging for drinks, charging for karaoke, limited seating... no thanks.
author: Lauren P.

description:
for a while now, late at night, i've walked into the sleepy kinokuniya building (thanks for the introduction, jason c!)...  goodnight, sophie's crepes.  goodnight, kinokuniya bookstore.  festa, you're still awake?  fantastic.  i'd like to tell you about my day via song over a bottle of sake.

...and that's how everyone should embrace festa.  it is the emotive haven for all.  whether you're heartbroken fools (who request 'always' by atlantic starr) or middle-aged businessmen who just came from gold club (who request 'i'm in love w/a stripper' by t-pain), this is where you are welcome.  ....except for the obnoxiously drunk.  you belong in a private karaoke room.  w/acoustically enhanced walls.  and linoleum floors.  

are you a karaokein fool?  songs are free before 9pm during the weekdays ($2/song otherwise).  if you see me there, let's sing a duet!  : )
author: Ting A.

description:
Overall, Festa can be a fun place, but get this:

One night, my friend couldn't drink anything alcoholic for some reason (I forget why), so he ordered a plain Diet Coke. Guess how much he was charged? $5. It was straight out of a can too. He thought, "Well, if you're going to make a 500% profit off a can of soda, can I at least have the rest of the can?" The answer is "NO." What kind of world do we live in? How do you say "wrong" in Japanese?
author: Lily T.

description:
Pros: 
-A great variety of songs
-Great drinks
-Good atmosphere

Cons:
-Very small place
-Karaoke should be fun, but it seemed like it was an American Idol competition that night.
-Drinks were expensive
author: Lenny C.

description:
FESTA!
Do you think Japanese are all crazy?
The answer is .....Yes.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xnSw-0Ut0jk

But there are few differences.

Japanese from Japan, as JJ.
Japanese from Hawaii, as JH.
Japanese from North America, as JNA.
Japanese from South America, as JSA.
Korean from Japan, as KJ
Chinese from Japan as CJ.
Philippino from Japan, as PJ.

They are all crazy ass and grew up with Japanese language. 
In my case is, I do feel close to all of them.

JH and PJ, I think because we are both in a small Island.
KJ and CJ they have been there for a long enough and many of them become real JJ.
JNA is most different than others.
Even though you have parents both from Japan, grew up in North America does make separates.
Separates what?
What happens living North America?
Well, you know, 
Fat, laud, baseball cap, T-shirts, shorts, FXXXin' birkenstock, white socks and sneakers,.... those.
No, that's not a point. 
That's a good part of US.
Do wear whatever you want, but I don't. I just hate shorts.

Thing is this, if they speak more text book perfect Japanese gets more obnoxious because sometimes missing the etiquette.
I don't really care all hysteric-Japanese etiquette but there is something you shouldn't say certain thing in Japanese especially to older man.
To speak older Japanese men is annoyingly difficult because they are such an arrogant prick sometimes.
Am I arrogant prick sometimes?
FXXX No, well, I try not to.

Translate perfect Japanese from English does not make a perfect communication yet between real persons.

But, Karaoke?
Karaoke.
Kuh lah oh kay?
Key raw o kee?
Do I Karaoke? Hell No.
I was always Karaoke hater.
I thought Karaoke is such a pathetic Japo-thing.

But talking about communication.

I found out Karaoke is the thing, universally effective to get together, to be happy to all kind.

I had a great Karaoke time at Festa in the west building at Japan Town.
It's a small but nice, modern, cozy and cool place for Karaoke & drinks.
There are really cool & nice bartenders.

I think there were 5 different group of people but it was like a talent show.
I liked that no one was pushing me to sing on the stage!
That was great. If you don't want to, it's OK. You can have fun too like I did.

I still think the guy sang Xanadoo and the theme song for Hanshin Tigers were BLAST!
Can you imagine that all of us were singing so loud Xanadu?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7m1UWSD-FaA&feature=related

Oh FXXX Yeah, we were so gay and I loved it!

But the greatest singers were following:
Berna Diva
Gracy Pho
Kay Jay. she isn't Korean Japanese.

No one can beat them. No one. So as Ed M.
It was his birth day party but we forgot all about it but just singing.
Happy Birth day Ed!
author: Nobu K.

description:
WHOA totally didn't notice I hit the 100 review mark and didn't do anything for it!  Oh well, for my one hundred and FIRST review I will write about a little karaoke bar called FESTA.  

Came here for Aileen's unbirthday last weekend and it was pretty awesome.  Not only did our group of 8 make up practically 50% of the patrons, but by the end of the night we were friends with (almost) everyone else at the bar.  Yes, that includes the table of world travelers from Japan and Germany, the table of SoCal Koreans, and the brave solo artists at the bar.  It does not however, include the group of hooligans in newsboy caps and plaid scarves who thought singing as loudly and as annoyingly as possible would make everyone like them.  I guess that only works in the movies.  

All in all it's a chill place and an (almost) judgment-free zone for the performers.  Drinks are pricey but hey it's Japantown.  Also, there's a 10 dollar cover if you wanna reserve a table (comes with 2 free songs).  I think they lowered it to 8 bucks for us though because we were awesome or something.  

Songs are 2 bucks each if you're buying them a la carte.  Never been to a karaoke bar where you had to pay for the individual song.  But then again I don't go out that much.  Only enough to make it to my ONE HUNDRED AND FIRST YELP REVIEW.  WOOP WOOP!!

Thanks for the memories, y'allz!
author: William S.

description:
If men didn't find me repulsive (and trust me, the feeling is mutual), this is the kind of place I would go on a date. It's tucked into Japantown and you feel as if you are in Tokyo, or the kind of place I imagine Tokyo to be: excessively priced drinks (9 dollars for a gin and tonic!? what am I, in Vegas?) and a fake skyline everywhere, with drunk old men trying to cop a feel on my hot friends. 

Anyway, as a place to do karaoke, Festa is just okay. They charge per song (inexcusable, especially since there is no KJ) and this is the kind of place you will hear 8,000 renditions of Sweet Caroline in one night. 

However, as a place to close out the night and ogle a cute bartender, it gets 4 shining stars.
author: Maria D.

description:
the bartenders are always cute and polite.
the videos need an upgrade into this century.
the drinks are pricey for a place that's essentially inside a strip mall.
thanks, that is all.
author: Sally T.

description:
The only reason this place gets 2 stars is because it's small and dispenses alcohol, thus enabling me rock out to NIN in front of strange 50 year old men.  I would really chalk that up to beer and patronage, though...

Ordering a drink here must be a joke.  In theory, there are two bartenders.  Keep in mind that this place is the size of a large closet.  Not only do the bartenders ignore you while you wait at the bar to order, but when you actually lean over, wave them down and ask politely to order a drink, they still ignore you.  It's so absurd, I have to assume they think I shat on their shoes a few minutes prior.  

When I finally forced myself upon one of them and ordered 2 drinks, they gave me one.  I had to do the whole song and dance again (with no one else at the bar!) to get the other.  I then asked to open a tab.  They ran the credit card and gave it back right away.   The whole joke of a process took 20 minutes.

They also charge for songs intermittently.  One song is $2, the other is $3, and the other is free.

Oh, and the drinks that take 20 minutes to order?  Overpriced and small.
author: Christine M.

description:
This is a quaint little karaoke bar in Japantown, in the Kinokuniya building plaza area.  I remember a couple years ago it was dark and tired, with ancient Japanese patrons belting out oldies on stage.  Now its updated, better lit, and filled with younger folks singing their hearts out in front of everyone, publicly humiliating themselves like the karaoke gods intended.

The big Japanese beers here are ten bucks.  A carafe of cold sake will set you back about thirty bucks.  Being the Asian math whiz that I am I asked my drunken buddy from LA, would you rather have another sake or 3 big bottles of beer?  Not the math whiz but a practical fellow of course he picked quantity over quality.

I came here again with another friend from LA, in town for training this week.  She was dying to go out since she has 3 kids and her husband hates dancing, which is normal, doesn't drink, which is kinda abnormal, and doesn't like making a fool of himself in public singing karaoke, which hmmmm, is kinda normal.

I ordered a glass of sake and she got the lichee cocktail.  Oh the lichee was incredibly good.  So I made a pact with her.  I'll continue ordering sake for myself and foofoo drinks for her.  Then I'll drink half her drinks and we'll go through the entire foofoo menu... that way I can secretly indulge in my foofoo drink passion while maintaining some semblance of my masculinity.  Finally I gave up and just ordered myself a foofoo drink.  I just drank my pear cosmo like the man that I am... whatever that means.  

Overall the lichee cocktail was by far the best.  An extra star for that plus the cool vibe.
author: Bryan K.

description:
I have a confession to make! Promise not to tell anyone?

Okay... I have a fetish for people speaking the Japanese language... Is that weird? So if you ever see me; please don't (and by that, I mean please do) bust out with the Japanese... You'll make me weak in the knees and have butterflies in my stomach.

So I wrote my chinese name on a piece of paper and challenged Koji (bartender) to read it. He had me clapping like the happiest sea lion in the world!

This place is small, but cozy. I don't think they even have their own restroom, you'll have to use one somewhere in the plaza.

But don't worry, you won't drink to the point where you'll throw up; because it would be such a waste to throw up 9-12 dollar delicious, well-made cocktail drinks!

I remember long ago when I made a promise to myself that I'd never sing at a karaoke bar... 

I broke that promise.

               I got up and sang my two-dollar song, "More Than Words" by Extreme.

Thank God I had the balls and liquor courage to do that... Because I ain't doing that again!!!

Now what the hell did he put in my drink to get me to do that???
author: Nance W.

description: I came here on Saturday night around 8 pm and the place was  packed. Luckily our friends had gotten tables for us, so we don't have to wait long for. table. i ordered peach Bellini and it was ok. A little bit sweet to my liking and a little to pricey. The crowd was great, and some people really have good voice. it was entertaining.  The spund system was good, song options were many and up to date. $2/song was ok, although you can wait for some time for your song to show up. i had a good time and would come back.
author: Bibi B.

description: I honestly do not understand the low scores given to Festa so far. I've found the staff to be attentive and fun, the drinks strong and delicious, and the song selection better than almost every karaoke place I've been to in the city. The stage can seem intimidating but the truth is the crowd and staff always appreciate and applaud every performance. Very accommodating, fun, and festive!
author: Christopher D.

description:
So this place used to be Sachi, which i heard was pretty fun for Karaoke in a group setting...tonight was not the case.  I believe the new ownership just took over mid Dec and did a great job on the layout and design aspects of this very intimate lounge.

Had a fun time with Mike telling Aaron and I about how Nancy Pelosi has screwed up things for all us men in SF- being she is from here and that SF women are already very well u know where iam going with this.  I was cracking up all night on how animated and excited he was on Pelosi ruling the US.  

Seating is comfortable and service was just above normal.  I think this place has potential, especially if more people discover this lil nook right across from Kinokuniya Bookstore.  Stuck with Gin&Tonic for the evening and had an okay cheeseplate.
author: omar b.

description: The only way a karaoke bar can beat Festa is if the Bon Jovi, Guns 'N Roses, and Elton John songs are actually being sung by Bon Jovi, Axl Rose, and Sir Elton John.  Don't let the unassuming entrance and small size fool you, as this intimate bar packs a serious punch.
author: Mark B.

description:
I LOVE watching douchebags and B&T sorority girls get drunk and beg for attention as much as the next person, but this is going a little far. I felt like I was in a bar in Lafayette during Spring Break and all the seniors were home to get drunk and screw like they did back in high school.

However, if you have friends like mine, the Party Olympics will be easily won and before you know it, the Chets and the Chips and their drunk groupies will disappear (possibly dropping all of their money for you on their way out- thanks again!) and you will be left with a cozy bar, a little stage, and a decent sound system and song selection (this is karaoke, bitches). 

Drinks cost a fortune (as in- you're likely to promise your first born in exchange for a well drink) and they're not that strong. So it's a good thing those yuppies got sloppy and left my dog and I with fistfuls of cash to cover all those vodka sodas. Good times! And right near my house. Three stars.
author: Autumn K.

description:
BEST.PLACE.EVER.  I'm not a lover of karaoke, but I LOVE FESTA.  I usually refer to this place as SHOGO'S! (let's go to SHOGO'S!) because he's one of the bartenders (this chill Japanese guy who's in some punk Japanese band), and, for some reason, around the end of the night, we start yelling his name over and over again (SHOGOOOOO!! SHOGOOOOO!).  Usually, it's while we're trying to shove a shot down his throat.  Whatevs.  

Anyways, it's a small, kinda cheesy room with a bar, some seating, and a stage - none of this private room crap.  Song selection is pretty good (Japanese, Mandarin, Cantonese, prob Korean and of course, English) and they're pretty current.  People who frequent the place appreciate good singing but appreciate it even more if you just lay it all out there on stage.  Just belt it, who freaking cares if you're not an awesome singer and don't know all the words?!  EVERYONE ELSE THERE SINGS WITH YOU!  EVEN IF IT'S IN A LANGUAGE THEY DON'T KNOW!!  It's like one big happy family!  You may not get all the songs you put in, but that doesn't mean you can't sing along with everyone else's!  

Not for those looking for a quiet place to sing every song they know.  Cuz it ain't gonna happen.  At least on Fridays and Saturdays.  Only thing is drinks are on the pricier side so a little pre-partying wouldn't hurt.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I karaoke a lot, and Festa is my favorite place to karaoke in SF. It's the perfect mix of intimate space, public stage, and convenient bar at the ready--instead of having to smuggle alcohol into those little karaoke studios. Plus, Festa has the best song selection--other studios either don't have a lot of good songs or the musical accompaniment sounds like a 7-year old playing on their Casio keyboard for you. And let's not even talk about the weird videos other studios show while your song is playing.

I've witnessed others having a bad time at Festa, and it's usually because they're totally hammered or they expect Diva service. Public drinking and karaoke can get really messy, and I often sympathize with the staff at Festa because the crowd often gets unruly, especially towards the end of the night.
