I highly recommend going to Festa early in the evening during the week. (The drinks are cheaper and songs are free before 9:30.) All of your requests will be played immediately and you get excellent service. Once the place gets packed around 9:30/10pm, all hell can break loose, and at that point you just need to go with the flow.
author: Jane R.

description:
OK here's the date: 

1) Sammy Hagar concert at the Fillmore 

2) Pancho Villa Taqueria for tacos and beer 

3) Festa Wine & Cocktail Lounge for Karaoke 

Is this a weird date?!  YES, it really really is.  Was it awesome to be the first person to have to sing in front of a crowded room of blank faced Japanese men, YES, I seriously kick ass at Whitesnake songs so that was no problem.  Bizarre but cool that on said date we did not one but TWO (God I'm sure everyone was SOO sick of us) duets, one to summerlovin' (yes, we did that, everyone groan) and one to Patience by G n' R.  God, I mean really this was the most unconventional date in the history of the universe but also super duper fun.  This karaoke bar RULES. 

Apparently the dating bar has been set, I can't really humiliate myself any more than I already have with this guy so the door is wide open.  Perhaps on the next date we will go to a mime class or improv, really the sky appears to be the limit.
author: Claire C.

description: Nice design for such a small place. However, beware of the cost. In addition to the $9 well drinks (and you'll be sold bottled water if you ask for water), there can be a cover charge of $10 per person, plus a charge of $2.00 per song, should the owner choose! Was totally surprised when asked to pay for selecting a song at a karaoke bar!
author: yaji-san k.

description: We love Festa!  It's a small, fun Karaoke bar in Japantown.  Good Karaoke selection, the service is great and prices are reasonable.  And there's always a fun crowd.
author: AJ L.

description: It's my favorite bar in San Francisco. Nice wine selection, the staff is very friendly and accommodating. I always have a great night there when I'm the area.
author: Miyuki T.

description:
When you're rolling to a karaoke joint with someone who considers the Art of Karaoke more of a Bloodsport than an Art, you know you're in for a good time.

I'd argue that the ambiance of Festa is worth the trek to Japantown alone. Then again, I was really drunk when we got there. There's really no excuse for the wallet-walloping drink costs & the $2/song request fee.

Seriously? You're CHARGING for each request? Aren't we supposed to just TIP really well so that you'll play them? They're really not down with Formalities here.

Still, a great time was had by all, & this is definitely the kind of bizarre place you will feel priviledged to close your night out at. Just make sure you save Guns N' Roses for the finale, because there's really no way you're going to be able to sing anything else after shredding your vocal chords on that Axl impression.
author: Pete J.

description:
"There is NO WAY I am singing!  I am SO scared!"

45 minuets later...

"Honey, this is your 6th song in a row, would you please get off the stage?" 

What can I say?  Cute, cozy, inviting place + Sake + Sake + Sake + Sake = me singing in Japanese without speaking a word of it; going on stage JUST to dance; and going back this Friday to do it all over again.
author: Tati K.

description:
What do you say about a Karaoke bar the size of a doctor's office waiting room that has lots of asian pop and at least one Children of Bodom song in its songbook, and a bartender with sideburns that extend down onto his neck (Does this count as a neckbeard? why are there no web pages mocking this?) and six dollar bottles of sapporo?

If you think of something, let me know. I'm drawing a blank for this review.
author: matthew r.

description: Hands down the best Karaoke bar in California, let alone San Francisco, possibly the WHOLE world! For all the one-star no-life, haters below, if you come to a karaoke bar expecting white-tablecloth customer service, well, you have a one-star brain! The point of this place is that you come, have a fantastic time, sing your heart-out right before you black out, and be sure to black out so that the next time you come back it's all new to you, so even if you did have shitty service - who cares! And on that note, in fact, the staff are awesome, good friends, great people, lovers, and Masae is simply the best. Rock-on Festa - I think I have been there, but I never can quite remember. LOVE IT!
author: Stuart C.

description:
Had a fun time singing "Anyway You Want It".  Did you ever try to karaoke a Journey song?  No.  Well, Steve Perry can sing.  Or could sing.  And I'm no Steve Perry, but I try, except without the mullet and the cheesy 80s moustache.
Small place.  
Cool stage backdrop good for pictures.  
Has Hawaiian songs in the book too.
author: Kev M.

description: Ah! This place is one of my friend's favorite places for karaoke. This is a nice little bar and karaoke bar. Their lychee martini is yummy and the service is very good here. The only down side to this is that it's so busy on Friday and Saturday nights. If you get there after 10pm, it will be standing room only! Other than that, great place to chill, sing a little, and hang out with friends over a couple of drinks.
author: Eva Y.

description:
Leave your dignity at door.  This is the effing real deal, the Karaoke BAR.  None of that bullshit booths with people humming along...  It's just you and the strangers.

There is an intense correlation between utter excitement and the anticipation of being possibly humiliated.  The latter usually breeds the excitement, I think.  But ultimately the environment at Festa is more than friendly, as long as you're drinking.  

And be warned: Sweet Caroline is the herpes of Karaoke song.  You'll be guaranteed to hear it for days, annoyed, yet incapable of getting rid of it.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
One of my favorite spots!  They are oh so very accommodating when let's say I get the urge to pop in and sing a song right before closing time.  Excellent customer service.  A fabulous selection of songs.  And the drinks and cocktails are super yum!  Who could ask for anything more really?  
This might just be one of the Best karaoke spots in the Bay Area!
author: Alisyn g.

description:
Love Love Love this place!!! I have been inspired to take singing lessons and learn Japanese after staying at this place at this place for hours when I only randomly walked in with a friend to see what this place was about.

I plan on making this a regular hangout!!! The owner and the service is awesome and the crowd is friendly. This little gem of a venue is going to be discovered by the rest of San Francisco soon...
author: Krystle M.

description:
This review should be prefaced by an admission:  I love Japan.  I don't mean I love Japan the way a person might love water skiing or chili dogs.  I love Japan the way you loved the girl you had a crush on in seventh grade.  About a year after I moved to Japan, I realized that if Japan had been personified as a woman, I would have either married her or gotten arrested by the Japanese Godzilla-helmet wearing police for stalking her, depending on how I did.  (And no, I didn't marry a Japanese woman as a way of fulfilling that strange desire and projecting it onto a person...that would have just been weird.)

So instead, in the many years since I've been back in America since living there, whenever I wander into places that are truly Japanese, I have a feeling of nostalgia that colors my judgment.

That would explain my behavior at Festa the other night.  Or it could be the drinks.  Both are perfectly plausible explanations.

So for starters, it's in Japantown and the bar is populated primarily by Japanese people.  I speak Japanese almost fluently (take note, Nance W. :) )  but of course, no one expects me to, so I get in what we used to call the 'language bubble' in these places.  The language bubble is a situation where nobody expects you to speak a certain language, so they feel free to speak in that language, often in ways they wouldn't if they knew you could understand them.  

I knew this was a real Japanese karaoke bar for two reason:  the menu was small and had overpriced 'sunaku' (that means 'snacks') including the 'assorted plate' for $10, which was about 7 grapes, some cheese and crackers straight from nabicso and some kamaboko slices (don't ask.)

The second and more important reason is that everyone was doing what karaoke is really for:  humiliating themselves equally.  It's one of the ways of leveling society in Japan.  You bow to people all day higher or lower based on your social status in Japan, but once you're at the karaoke bar, everyone sucks equally, even the boss.  It's a pretty awesome tradition.

After a couple of fun-loving, corn-fed midwestern gals left the place after singing everything in the Michael Bolton catalog, it was time to get down to business.  Japanese songs were sung.  French 75s from earlier in the evening were impairing my ability to read kanji, and I never got around to singing my favorite Japanese karaoke song, 'Shima Uta.'  Buy me a drink there sometime and I'll do it.

Instead, I was pushed up onstage and made to sing (I forgot about this but it happens a lot) Elvis.  I decided that the thing to do was to just fully own it, so when 'Jailhouse Rock' came up, I just rocked that joint.  To paraphrase Samuel Jackson, to them I was Elvis.

Then came 'Are You Lonesome Tonight?' which was fine until I realized there's about a 2 minute speech in the middle of that song.  ("I wonder if...you're lonesome tonight..."  Itunes it if you've never heard that part.)  Anyway, it was effective, judging by the reaction of the bartender, but after that we still had to take it up tempo, as one more sappy tune like that would have killed me.

Finally, we got , as all white people in a Japanese karaoke bar must, to the Beatles.  After one rendition of  "If I fell," I wanted to try it again, with my college buddy singing harmony, so from the stage, with microphone in hand, I asked them to play it again, but I spoke Japanese.  This was almost more than the room could bear.  What kind of a freak was I?  The language bubble was thoroughly popped, but the rockin' still didn't stop.

Finally, at the end of the night, the bill was inexplicably a lot higher than we thought, which almost brought a tear of joy  to my eye because that's always what happens in Japan too.  Plus, I wasn't paying.

Don't go to Festa (or any Japanese karaoke bar) hung up on singing well, or you'll make a jackass of yourself.  Just remember three words the local barkeep at the karaoke place where I lived used to say to us:  you must enjoy.

That's right.  You MUST enjoy.  The most Japanese thing of all is that just because it's fun doesn't mean you have a choice.

Festa is definitely on my list of places I must enjoy again when I'm in SF.
author: Jim M.

description:
Festa's is my new #1 spot for karaoke in the city. I was a latecomer to Masae's takeover from Sachi, so I was surprised to see the remodel and the name change.  And things just got better from there.

Ken, the manager/bartender, brought us up to speed on the change. The place looks terrific now. More seating, better lighting (not brighter, just better), new karaoke system and much nicer staff.

There are several English books here, so it's not just Japanese songs.  Yes, the songs are $2 per, but worth the price.  You can now use a wireless mic if you don't want to sing on stage (unless it's super busy like last night and then only special people like me get to use the wireless; otherwise, it gets lost in the crowd).

I used to introduce a lot of people to Sachi's. I'll be stopping by even more often now.

UPDATE: And I'm bringing Mani.
author: Keith K.

description:
I've learned some tough lessons at Festa.

Japanese businessmen love songs by Britney Spears and will get up and dance with you making you feel like the young, hot version of Britney - not the freaky, can't keep her children, shave her head Britney.  

Japanese businessmen do NOT, however, like Barry Manilow.  They will stare at you stonefaced and make you feel like a fallen star.  They are probably right.
author: Beth F.

description:
Um why haven't I ever known about this place before???  Yeah, hello.  I'm ashamed for being a native and not knowing about this cute, tidy, little place where I would not be ashamed to take people to.

My cousin knew about this place and he took me and our other cousin visiting from NYC and I was like "where the hell are we going?"  And low and behold a little bar where like one couple was drinking at the bar and chatting with a sweet waiter.  But I also felt like only early-bird special citizens would be kicking it here but none were in sight.

We ordered drinks and because only the couple and the waiter were singing I mustered up some courage and sang a song.  Then like 15 minutes later 2 huge groups of white people came in and started singing and drinking.  I was like "how did they know about this place?"  They must have Yelped it.  LOL.
author: Susan C.

description:
Ordinarily, I'm pretty much scared shitless at the though of standing up in front of a crowd of strangers and singing karaoke. This place is just cozy enough, however, that it really rubs the edges off of my stage fright. 

The cocktails are little bit weak, considering the price tag ($9-12). 

They really reverb up the mics to sweeten your voice. 

One time I sang Just Like Heaven, and ended up singing into both mics at once. I think I even sat down on the stage for a little bit. It must've made a pretty strong impression on my friend Dan, because he brings it up every time this place gets mentioned. 

One of these days I'm going to find a song that I can flap my arms and jump up and down to. 

Their English-language pop menu somehow skews towards a slightly new-wave/alternative sort of vibe. For instance, you can find Jon Spencer Blues Explosion songs on their menu, but no Space Oddity. 

What am I gonna fatally embarrass myself with if there's no Space Oddity?
author: Gopal R.

description:
Small, intimate, public karaoke bar that delivers on big entertainment and guaranteed to make you feel like a rock star even though your caterwauling is making everyone's ears bleed.  

By small and intimate, I mean just that.  The place is no bigger than a two car garage.  There are no booths, just you, the stage, and untapped glory.  You may be intimidated by singing in public, but you need not fear this place because no one here will judge you.  Everyone is supportive, they know the lyrics, and they'll sing along with you.  Afterward, when you're done making a mockery of yourself, the audience will clap and cheer you on.  There's no greater ego boost, deserved or not.

I, myself, am a terrible singer.  But the atmosphere, and camaraderie lead me to fearlessly sing My Girl with fearless abandon.  I surprised myself.  Sure, liquid courage helps somewhat, but the enthusiasm of this place is infectious. 

That, combined with the clean, cushy interior sets this place apart from other whole in the wall places that make you afraid for your safety.
author: Baldwin H.

description:
I love this bar - small and cozy, but loads of new people every weekend to satisfy my inner sociologist (I love observing what people sing and drink). I stumbled upon it just about a year and a half ago, always passing by it on my many jaunts to Japantown but never going in, as I was always on my way home when it was just opening up. Finally, at last year's Cherry Blossom Festival, I was in the J-Town mall late enough to take a peek in - and have loved it ever since. Now, I'm there so often that it's like my own personal "Cheers," but with more singing. Well, the bartenders and I don't know each other by name, but they know me by face, voice & drink (Makers & Coke, almost always at the ready with a smile as soon as I'm spotted). 

And really, isn't all that matters? 

Well, that and lots of songs to choose from, which it also has - you've got Chinese, Korean, Spanish and Tagalog besides your requisite English and Japanese... although I'm a little bummed "River Deep, Mountain High" isn't on there (or is very hard to find). Eh, no one's perfect. 

But I'll still be there almost every weekend - I'm that girl with the big ol glasses and curly hair with a glass of whiskey in one hand and a mic in the other.
author: Joanne C.

description:
Pros: cozy atmosphere, near home, nice staff
Cons: pricey drinks and charges per song, outdated song selections (especially for Japanese songs)
author: Takashi Y.

description: I am not a big karaoke person but as far as karaoke places go, Festa is pretty cool.  The fake scenic background is perfect for photo opportunities, and the mini-stage is also great for you and your back-up singers.  There is a pretty good selection of songs, though they were missing one of my friend's favorite karaoke songs - Bye Bye Bye by N Sync.  The drinks are a bit pricey - $9 for specialty drinks like their martinis - but tasty (I had the lychee martini).  The place is pretty small so if you're going with a large group (like I did), you should call ahead so space is reserved because the place was packed when we were there.
author: Wendy L.

description: Totally agree with Brenda T. regarding Festa Cocktail Lounge!  I've never been to any Karaoke that charges customers $2 per song that they sing. I have been to Karaoke bars which are more upscale than this one wherein you get private rooms to use and sing your lungs out but does not charge for the number of songs you would want to sing.  Not coming back.
author: Lucy L S.

description:
Best karaoke bar in SF.  Great selection, real track music or at least close to it (not that crap muzak they use at Nap's).  Unquestionably worth the $2/song.

My performances last week:
"Dreams" by Van Halen (ie: Van Hagar)
"Just Like Paradise" by David Lee Roth
"Goin' Back to Cali" by Notorious B.I.G.
"Mr. Roboto" by Styx

...plus some more that I can't recall right now.

I need to hang out in Japantown more often.
author: Doctor L.

description: Here's what you get on a Fri/Sat night:  the place is packed, the cost for a song is $2, you hand your $10 bill to the karaoke attendant who asks you if you want change. Obviously you do. But not if you want your song to come up in the next 90 minutes. She/he takes your $8 tip and then calculates your spot in the sea of paid slips. $20 will get you pretty close to the front. We learned that $10 will get you slot #7.  When only half the words to our duet came on, we asked for a refund or a free song. They explained that it's "the machine." No refund. Oh, you'd like another song? $2. Terrible. Go to Do Re Mil.
author: Ilona G.

description: Came back into town recently to visit and of course I had to stop by. Had a blast and their lychee martini's are still the best around :)
author: alita c.

description:
LOVED IT!!!

A friend of mine had a birthday party here and it was such a fun experience! The place itself is pretty small.. you go in, there's a bathroom in the hallway (which was spacious and clean!), then the room opens up with the bar on the right and the tables and stage. That's it. But it is the fact that it's small that makes it even better! You get a really warm feeling, everyone is friendly to each other and the popular songs get sung by the the whole crowd. 

$2 a song, with a really good selection (it's guaranteed that everyone will find something they'll want to sing) and still the feeling of being a star when you get on the stage. The wait for the songs isn't bad either, and the waiting list is displayed at the end of every song so people can get ready. Overall, a really fun place with reasonable prices and good service. I had one drink and it was strong, and I'm sure every one else's were too. My only thing was that one of the two microphones wasn't working as well as the other one, and being a Singstar on Singstar.. I've grown to be a little picky about sound. 

Despite that, I can't wait to come back and fill the place up with my singing friends!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jade T.

description:
I always have a good time here.  The bartenders are excellent, I'm always telling my friends this is a great place to get a drink.  As others have said, the drinks are $8-$12 but the quality is high, in my experience.  And the staff are very friendly and quick to serve.

This is a fantastic place to bring a small group of friends (recommend a weeknight - the weekends get crazy).  Very warm, cozy atmosphere and you get to sing often.
author: Craig J.

description:
I call this place "The Water-Hoarders" due to the surreal struggle i had getting a glass of precious hydration in this pace. I walked in with a group of about 8 friends around 11. The server asked me for my order first, and being that we had just walked about 15 blocks, I said I just wanted a "water for now." The waiter told me I had to order something else. I thought he might be joking, so I just stared at him. I told him I was going to order a drink in a bit, and he said "everybody lies and says that. You have to order your drink now or else i will charge you for the water." I turned to my friend and audibly requested that she order the controversial H2O on my behalf. She ordered a beer and a water, and when he brought back all the drinks for the table he shot me a dirty look and ceremoniously sat the water down RIGHT in front of my friend. 
We all sang a bunch of songs and actually had a pretty good time (although I credit that to the musical stylings of my crew). We were not at all shocked to find that when our checks came we found mysterious and random charges. I asked why my $9 lychee martini (which was made with well vodka and was one of the worst I've had) came out at 12. The bartender told me "sometimes the owner adds a gratuity. If you have an issue you are going to need to take it up with her." The owner was glaring at our group (which brought in the bulk of their business that night and made friends with most of the other patrons) so I just paid and left. Even though I begrudgingly admit it is a fun environment, I will NEVER go here again and encourage you to find a place that does not bite the hand that feeds.
author: Dinelle L.

description: I was there last saturday and the bartender called one of my friends a jackass after he left for no reason. After i asked him why, he was very unapologetic and was then rude to the girls I was with. None of us had any bad interactions with this bartender that night so he was just taking out some aggression on us. Not worth your time. A far better place is Town Studio right around the corner for Karaoke. Great place and extremely friendly staff. Don't waste your time here.
author: Mike L.

description:
Warning do not go here if you're feeling EMO.  You'll end up crying in your martini glass after hearing every breakup/emo songs in the book.  This may cause you to drink even more and then to eventually text your ex something along the lines of, "why did we break up again?"

"Because you cheated on me bitch!"
kidding.

The lichee martini is like no other.  At first I was a bit iffy about the place.  I mean it really is as small as my dining room and you have to PAY to sing karaoke.  Also the drinks are overpriced.  But man, they really know how to make good drinks.  After 4 glasses, you'll definitely have no shame singing along.  Another thing, you'll spend the whole time at Festa planning to download the songs you hear, but fail to do so when you go home because you'll totally forget what songs they were.  Damn Sake Martini!

I enjoyed my experience...
+3.5 for the amazing lichee martini and for the mixed crowd.  Maybe because the place seems small and intimate or because everyone there was drunk...regardless, we all had no shame in making a fool of ourselves.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: a fun place but don't take it too seriously   on NYE table service was a bit slow but so what, we went to the bar and got drinks  the crowd was fun and the place had a cool vibe!
author: Vivek V.

description: This is a follow-up review - After 4 years and counting Festa remains the best, coolest, most authentic Karaoke bar in SF - bar none.  The bartenders know their stuff, so a visit to Festa is a good occasion to try something exotic - and it doesn't hurt your performance either.
author: Paul J.

description:
I would like to being with... The owner? The fancy lady who is also in this pictures... she does look mighty fancy, and that fancy factor alone gave you a star, so it saved you from a two star rating. 

So lets begin... 

1. You are a small little venue that makes it hard to believe that my imaginary manager would book a venue that small to rock out in. 

2. I guess your drinks are a bit pricey. I spent $22.00 on two drinks, and decided that:
-a. I will not be drunk enough to rock, out especially in a venue so small that it wouldn't be able to contain all the glory that is... DANTASTICO! 
-b. I had already had 2 liters of beer for free so I wasn't jones'n for more alcohol. 

3. What the hell city scape in the background of the stage is that supposed to be? Toronto? 

4. I will admit, it is one of the more... fancy karaoke bars I have been to, especially in San FranDisco. 

5. The patrons there are magical. Everyone clapped for everyone, everyone was a back up singer for everyone, even if they didn't know the words to the songs... ITS KARAOKE there are words on the t.v screens so everyone was able to do back up vocals. 

6. You have a good list of song options, BUT not a great list of song options... yeah I said it. 

7.You turned me down! YOU TURNED ME DOWN WHEN I WAS GOING TO SING BOHEMIAN RHAPSODY!.... Whats wrong with yoooou!? Don't you know who I'm not!

all in all, it was quite an enjoyable night.
author: danny e.

description:
I've walked past this place so many times I can't even count but I checked it out on the suggestion of some yelpers. My friend (a gal who also turns out to be a powerful singer) and I walked in just to see what was going on. I was a bit dismayed at first because it was empty but we asked to see their song book. 

Wow! They have an up-to-date selection. The cool barkeep and cute waitress spoke BOTH Japanese and English so I flipped back and forth with them all night.  They had such classes as "yume no naka", and "Space battleship Yamato" and a few others.

The crowd that showed up later was quite mixed in age and race and remarkably supportive. Totally a bomb place to do duets, so make sure you bring a friend!
author: Takeo E.

description: Festa = Fun!!!  This little bar/lounge is located in the Japantown shopping mall.  The bartenders are super outgoing and fun and make you feel like they are your best friend by the end of the night.  Drinks were okay (lychee martini = yum, dirty martini = nasty).  It costs $2 to sing a song and, since there were only 10 people there, I sang 4 songs and my husband sang 2.  I definitely recommend this bar!
author: Alena W.

description:
WHOAH. Was this place shady? Check yes!

I have been here a few occasions prior and had quite a pleasant evening, but apparently when you bring a large group of thirsty divas the shit hits the fan.

Yes, this place is cute, small, and the decorative atmosphere is lovely, but when taking into account the snobbery and rudeness of the people that work here, I will never ever come here again. And I highly recommend that you stray away from such businesses.

Shady example 1:

The large group that we were with opened a number of tabs. The same drinks were charged on multiple tabs. Sure, they wanted to take more of our money for booze, but they definitely weren't overwhelmingly excited to play the songs our party requested.

Shady example 2:

A friend of mine opened her own tab with a few drinks, put in a song when she arrived, and waited two hours. Her song never came up. People that came to the place AFTER her got multiple songs in. Upon asking the "KJ" if he lost it, he was--apparently--quite rude.

Shady example 3:

There were a number of tables reserved for the evening. That's fine. They sat us in the reserved section and said, "At 11:30 you'll have to find another table or stand." That was no big deal at that point. Come 11:30, we all get up and move to another section of the bar. I was sitting at a table for about 10 minutes, and the owner came up to me, placed a reserved place card, and said, "This table is reserved, you're going to have to move." She then goes to MY FRIENDS (who came later than the first wave of people) that I INVITED (to spend money at her corrupt establishment) and asks ME to move so they could sit down. It's a good thing I knew these people, seeing as they walked into the bar after me, or I would have been so much more disappointed than I already was. It was such a dick move--her judgment of socioeconomic class was very apparent as she asked the casually dressed brown man to move for the "classier" dressed white girls.

All in all, don't come to this place unless you're already friends with that owner that has the worst stink face I have ever seen. This place could really be awesome if the owner wasn't corrupt in her business decisions.
author: Diego B.

description: Love this place. It's intimate and they have a full bar. Costs $2 per song and sometimes you do wait awhile. Go early and get your songs in. Their list of songs is huge too. You go up on stage and can sing to your heart's content. I hate singing, but I got up there to sing with friends, of course. Great find in J-Town and way classier than do re mi (ew disgusting!)
author: Natalie S.

description:
This place had great service and great selection of songs.

The tinny midi music sound system wasn't great, but wasn't terrible either.

The reason this place gets one star was the pricing ambush. It is so freaking expensive for the thimble-full drinks you get it boggles the mind.

I know people think this place is charming and fun, which I agree with, but these guys knew what they were doing, and the drink prices and karaoke charge were not listed or mentioned. $9 for 1oz of whiskey is just criminal.

If you like even a single drink, don't go here, you will get ninja starred upon entrance.

Such a dissapointment, for your pocketbook's sake if not your own, don't even consider this place.
author: Chris M.

description:
So I'm Korean... and I've done more than my fair share of karaoke! While Festa isn't perfect, by any means.. they have an ammmmmmmmmazing selection of music! music! music! I was amazed and basically wanted to sing evvvvverything. 
Also, love the decor.
author: Lily K.

description: If there was a way to not give this place any stars I would.  It started out okay and fun was to be had by all.  But then things quickly turned around...the owner forced us to move from our long established seats in order to make room for the already crowded room.  Then if things couldn't get worse, they double charged us for three drinks and refused to fix it.  Never, ever, ever again will I enter this place.  Never.
author: Jessica J.

description: $5 sprites and unfriendly staff.  One star for cool location.  I think this place is homophobic.  C'mon this is SF, haven't you ever seen a drag queen before?
author: Molly G.

description:
I had very little expectations about coming here last night for my friend's birthday.  I am not a karaoke girl.. I sing in my car, I sing at concerts, heck I even sing in taxi cabs if I'm drunk enough!   But I'm not big on singing in front of crowds.

This place. Is. Awesome.  Great drinks--lychee martini, phone book sized song selection--in English and Japanese (if you're into Asian pop music).  Nice cozy environment and really really cool bartenders!  Thanks for cleaning up after us last night!
author: Miranda S.

description: This is a super cool spot for karaoke...well for watching other people. The bartenders selected a song for us, and it was so bad that we got booed off lol. However besides that, these are definitely some of the nicest bartenders in the city- a boy kept buying me shots and drinks, and I because they could tell I didn't want any of them (or need anymore), they kept swapping them out for non-alcholic versions. That was definitely a first. The only downfall was that I almost got my ass kicked by a very scary girl. I accidentally spilled a little of my drink on her purse and she was not happy about it. Luckily a random guy spent his time doing damage control and talked her out of it. How sweet!
author: Sonya D.

description:
I just celebrated my 30th birthday at Festa.  The tiny little karaoke bar was perfect for my cozy party of about 30 people.  The folks who run the place are super nice and friendly and the bar/lounge/bathroom are surprisingly clean.  They also let us bring in a birthday cake and provided a knife and extra paper plates at no charge.  

The crowd at Festa was awesome.  My friends and I pretty much took over the bar for the entire night and not only did no one complain, everyone sort of just joined in the party.  You can tell there were a few regulars but a couple of the groups looked like they just went to check it out and they were good sports and even helped us celebrate.

The best part was the cheesy backlit cityscape behind the stage which provided the most hilarious backdrop for photos!      

They charged us $10 a person cover since we were a large group and took up 80% of the bar but they also threw in 20 free songs which are otherwise $2 a piece.  

Despite the extreme smallness of the place or maybe because of it, I had a great time at Festa and would definitely recommend it to people who like karaoke.  It's a change from the usual bar night and even if you're not a singer, you'll be thoroughly entertained.
author: Winnie Y.

description:
Hot damn they charge $9 bucks for drinks, $4 for a cup of green tea, and $2 bucks for each song!  Ridiculous.  Also embarrassing is the size of Festa, maybe 400 square feet, you can see everything, and everyone from anywhere in the bar.  

Price gouging and claustrophobia aside, I like this place.  It's clean, efficient, and perfect for jeering or cheering your friends on.  Not to mention there's a fun cardboard skyline backdrop on stage, backlit with Christmas lights, and part of the ceiling twinkles with fake stars.  It makes all those sappy love ballads, and slow jams all the more authentic.  

Get in early.  I went from 8 pm and stayed till 2 am, and discovered it gets packed at  around 10:30 pm, and a second wave settles in at around 12:30 am.  

Overall, a nice establishment I could take my mother to.  

Note: the volume doesn't get adjusted.  Bring ear plugs, and fist wads of cash or plastic.  Some songs are in Japanese or Chinese (not sure), and the crowd is well-mannered clean, and wholesome.  For a dirtier night out- with cheaper drinkers, and cheaper people- I'm a fan of Encore on California St.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
Intimate.
And nothing beats watching your friends make complete fools of themselves after taking a few of Fernet- Branca.
author: Gabriela O.

description:
Brace yourself... this place is SMALL (maybe 400 square feet) and you have to be BOLD about karaoke. The selection is extensive, the sound is great, and -- for first timers -- the karaoke holds your hand well.
May we recommend doing what our friend Ahmed did and renting the joint for a couple of hours, filling it with friends who are VERY good singers, and enjoying the drinks and ambiance?
I only wish Festa had one or two REALLY good beers on tap and maybe something to nibble, since it's a bit of a umbrella-in kinda frou-frou cocktail bar... drinks fine for "Xanadu" and "Homeward Bound," but not as good for "Foxy Lady!"
author: Winter M.

description:
Wanting to sing a little to wind down a long night, I headed to Festa. I am starting to become a regular at this place for several reasons. The service is cool. The owner, Masae, is perfect to run this place. The setting has improved 100% over the previous management. They have a good selection of my favorite songs. The karaoke system works well. Stage and wireless mics. Cool patrons. It just feels at home. 

The bartender of the night was cool. He sported sideburns that were long, and looked as if they could double as knives, LOL!!! After a few beers, he whipped up my Blue Tokyo, in layers. It was a pretty drink to look at, and tasted great.  

Being a slow night, made it easy to get on the mic, but I must say that this place is fun when you have a lot of people who really get into the singing aspects.
author: Mike T.

description:
Yay Festa!  This place is great.  Damn expensive but oodles of fun.  And it never fails to impress; everyone I've brought here seems to agree it is like no karaoke bar they know.  Come to think of it, it kinda reminds me of the karaoke bar in "Lost in Translation" and if I came here one night and found Bill Murray covering Roxy Music, I might only be mildly surprised.  The space is super intimate which only makes the idea of getting on stage all the more dangerously enticing.  Oh yes, I've seen many a hardcore opponent of karaoke go down at Festa, try as they may!  

The best thing about this place?  Number one with a bullet: the stage backdrop!  I think the owner, who is cute as hell and saccharine sweet, nicked it from the set of a Cars video (I'm thinking specifically of "You Might Think", but any would do).  It's pure 80's class, which if you can remember wasn't very classy.  It's classy like that Nagel print you bought from Deck the Walls in '84.

Bring everyone you know here some night, maybe a Tuesday or Sunday night, and just take that joint over.  That's really the best way to do it.
author: Liz D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, especially after reading some good reviews about it.  I will NEVER return here.

Money grubbery - It is WAY too expensive.  My friend just had her birthday party there (weekend night) - they charged her a $10/person cover charge, my drink was $8 for a well drink, and then on top of that it was $2 PER song.  Then when she wanted to pull out her cake, they wanted to charge her an additional $20 to serve it.  So for 16 of us at the party to sing a song each (and have a SINGLE drink) it was $320!  You can get bottle service (including entry) at a shwanky night club for much less than that price.

Disorganization - On top of that they are incredibly disorganized with the karaoke.  Unlike other bars, which request people write their own names down on an organized song request form, this place hands you a blank piece of paper and no one writes their own name down.  When you hand it back to them, they put it in a disorganized pile of paper.  I put in my paper upon arrival at 9p and by 11p still it had not been entered in the machine (it shows the waitlist).  My friend paid for 20 songs for her party and had only used about 2-3 of them when I left - while the table next to us had one girl who went up three songs back to back.  Their complete lack of organization means a lot of the same people end up singing multiple times, and other people never get to go - all the while paying $2/song!  Other bars will usually let "new" people get priority to be more equitable.

Quality of atmosphere/service - 
1.  Bartenders both bartend and KJ which means they are overwhelmed (explaining the disorganization) but it means it takes a while to get a drink or submit a song.  They should delegate one person to KJ only.
2. The microphones are awful!  Granted it's a karaoke bar not a music studio or anything, but these are perhaps the worst I've ever heard.
3.  One redeeming quality is that the bar itself has beautiful lighting and wood paneling, and it is a small intimate environment like other reviewers say.
4.  They do have a large song selection - which is also a plus.

I strongly recommend against this place.  I usually only write yelp reviews when I love or hate a place.  I think it is not worth the money.  There are too many other great places in SF.   If you're reading this from the restaurant, I've offered constructive concrete changes that could improve your place of business.
author: N K.

description:
can two people step into a karaoke bar on a friday night, not sing, and STILL have a great time? 

the answer is a resounding, YES. 

they have the best j-video collection of songs i have ever seen, and the bar is intimate and fun. a lot of older japanese men mixed in with the crazy young and boisterous crowd. 

the bartenders are super cool and everyone in the bar is extremely friendly.
author: May T.

description: The place is a rip off vodka and a beer 17 dollars. Don't come here!!!!!!!
author: Brian P.

description:
this place marks the very first time i sang karaoke in public. i don't care what other people say: i have star quality, dammit!

i call my singing style "eccletic experimental yodel folk".
have you ever sang fleetwood mac's dreams in the voice of jennifer tilly and the timing of both tricky and prince circa 1995? didn't think so. cuz then you'd be biting my steez.

serenading my pitbull with my own rough rendition of george clinton's atomic dog while she stares at me with her ears bent back just doesn't count. NOBODY PUTS BABY IN THE CORNER!

so for all you jennifer greys out there with the fat luther vandross stuck inside of you, go to festa for your first stab at this obnoxious pasttime! the crowd is tolerant (and small), there's no interior visibility from the outside (so you can save face), they have a decent soju/sake selection, and the service is friendly.

oh, and it's LEGAL! it's a perfect stepping stone towards ultimate voluntary public humiliation, which is auditioning for american idol and not being picked, a la william hung.

go!
author: Vanessa D.

description: So fabulously giddy that they have S-Club 7's "Never Had A Dream Come True." You simply cannot deny the strange sense of liberation, of empowerment, that getting up on a mini stage and singing in front of total strangers gives! All of a sudden you find yourself grasping onto the mic just a little bit more, that sort of thing. Karaoke is to have fun and Festa, without a doubt, provides a fun atmosphere where patrons can sing the blues, wail about love, and anything else their little hearts desire. When there are more than 2 singers on stage, they ever so graciously provide another mic. Nice touch, as not everyone wants to be just another back up singer. Ahhh, minor detail: Requested water, and was brought a bottle of it. Hmmm. Like I said, minor detail. Belt it out, honey.
author: Mina S.

description:
ahaha i ALWAYS have fun here!!
there are definitely regulars that i always see no matter what day i go, but everyones nice, and its fun to sing in front of people

they've got a full bar, and cool people working there

def helps if u speak japanese (i don't).

the crowd is a mix of young asians in a group to old white guys there by themselves. whatever, everyone's there to have fun, and everyone does.

$2 per song, so make sure u make it count
author: Simon C.

description: A karaoke bar that puts that boom boom pow in their cocktails
author: Alex H.

description: You want to go karaoke, but you don't want to rent a room and you don't want to go to a big place that has a hundred people all trying to sing.   Festa to the rescue.  The drinks aren't cheap and the songs are $2, but that's good cause who wants to spend more than an hour in a karaoke place anyway?
author: Corey V.

description: Very cool 70s retro + loungey karaoke bar in the middle of the Japantown mall.  The drinks are a bit pricey and they charge $2 per song for karaoke, but the singers were all entertaining (esp Corey) and the bar offers a welcome respite from the mall atmosphere.
author: Sid D.

description:
After throwing a birthday party here for my boyfriend (nothing says love like public humiliation on a stage), I was horrified when I scrolled through my flipcam the morning after to see myself singing awkward renditions the likes of Johnny Cash, New Kids on the Block, and Olivia Newton-John.  Holy crap.  What happened that night?

Though I'm embarrassed to say I was only lucid for half the night, apparently that is the very essence of a really good time.  It seemed everyone else either didn't care, or rode the same shameless, tone-deaf bus that I did.

Needless to say, the drinks are strong.  REAL strong.  Pretty cool bartending crew.  I had reserved for a party of 12, so I had to pay about $10/head, PLUS 18% gratuity.  It's a bit steep for a kareoke bar, but given how packed it was, we were happy to have the prime real estate with a big table in the back.

By the end of the night, somehow an extra $34 got tacked onto the bill.  I'm pretty sure the final check was somewhere around $199 which already included gratuity.  That means, I had to have gotten out my little blackberry calculator and figure out 18% of $199 (the $34) - all in my totally inebriated state.  I don't remember doing it and was pretty unhappy to find that extra charge on my credit card a week later.  Now, the next part is what really made me like Festa - I called and left a message asking for a copy of the signed receipt. Masae, the manager who was out of town the day of my party, called me back personally to go over the charges.  We're still not clear on what happened that night.  Given my utter blackout, it's very possible I just made a mistake.  But she was happy to send me a credit for the extra amount to use the next time I went in - even though she said that amount probably went home with the bartenders and not to the bar.  And because of this I will definitely be going back.
author: Virginia L.

description: I come here a lot. I really like this joint cause of the karaoke, ambiance, and bartenders are cool. Sunny is an interesting character, he's one of the bartenders there. I love it when he sings L.O.V.E. I like the little stage too. I have a great time singing up there, I feel like a pop star sometimes! they also have newer songs than most karaoke spots I've been to in the past.
author: Kissy F.

description: I've spent two evenings at Festa.  Beautiful, intimate room, good cocktails and karaoke. Charging for each karaoke song on top of expensive drinks seems excessive, but I rolled with it.  I brought 30 friends there on my birthday, was happy to pay a serving fee for bringing my own birthday cake (to be expected in nice restaurants) I offered a piece to all the servers and was stunned when a bartender smiled at me later and pointed to my cake turned on it's side in a box on the floor next to the door.  Seriously,  WTF?!!!  Second visit I gave a credit card to run a tab.  Had 4 drinks and was presented with a bill for $70 with room to leave a tip.  When I asked for an itemized receipt, my drinks were not only overpriced, but an 18% service charge was added without explanation. I ordered these at the bar, not even table service.  I was then asked "wasn't I with a group of 6 or more?"  I've worked in restaurants and this is a dirty and greedy trick.  If I ever go back, I'll bring a flask.
author: J V.

description: Hey! I want to Festa with several friends last night again that was packed even on Thursday night, wow!! Understandable for its super fun venue to sign and drink! The staff were so cool to serve us even it was very busy and they even looked having fun! I like the fact that other customers were also fun feeling like my own friends. I will write again when I go again to Festa that would be very soon!!
author: MIBC G.

description: I have had some legendary evenings at this place, but the last time I went I left rather disappointed.  A friend and I wanted to go in for a drink and a song (drink for her, song for me for her =).  We sat down at the bar, were greeted immediately and given an English karaoke book.  My friend comes for the Lychee martini (with SKYY) which I have to admit, is a silent killer.  Delicious.  I had... regrettably... a five dollar bottle of Crystal Geyser.  I wish I'd have paid attention to the menu, but keep in mind, I did ask for a "glass of water, please."  Apparently, they do not offer water to their patrons.  The prices of drinks at Festa are astronomical, and there have been times where I felt like the large Sapporo was half water, but it all seemed tolerable when drunk and singing songs of joy and friendship.  It would have helped had either of the bartenders there cut us some slack and let us sing a song for the one dollar we had left after closing out our tab.  There's a ten dollar minimum for credit/debit card usage, and we weren't going to sit there and belt out five songs, so we had to accept the fact that rules is rules and sit there and listen to yet another rendition of Sweet Child o' Mine and the murder of All You Need is Love, while I tried desperately to convince myself I was drinking the best water on the planet.  "Now I gotta know what five dollar Crystal Geyser tastes like."  Festa... I love you and I will return, but man... I'll never order water again.
author: Matthew H.

description:
This place is all about community -- it's basically San Francisco's "Cheers" -- just where everyone is singing and even the most aloof manly-man warms up with lychee martinis. 

I've been coming to Festa for more than a year, and it only gets better and better for me and my friends who come one or two times a month. The bartenders are exceptionally nice, (Ken, Shogo, Satoshi) and Masae-san the owner treats us like family. We feel like family to them because this place is so small -- they make an effort to get to know their customers, but also it's part of their business: they depend on their customers to become regulars and support their bar. I've brought more than 30 different friends here over the past year and everyone leaves craving another go; it's just hard not to fall in love with the support always ready for the singer, the service always ready to ensure you have a great time.

I think any of the disgruntled Yelps on this place haven't given it enough of a chance or don't fully understand how hard it must be to crowd control this place given it's so small -- it can get really rowdy in there, people start screaming into the microphone, get so drunk they break glasses or tip over tables, and because they do have a reservation policy for larger groups, sometimes you do have to move for folks who've paid an extra cover.

I agree with a lot of the Festa regulars who've said it's even better on a weeknight; part of the "Cheers"-like draw. There have been many a work conflict or a friend disagreement thawed out by the incredibly fun and hilarious environment. I've never walked out of the bar without someone's email address for future karaoke nights. Also, you get to sing more often as fewer people are in the bar, and this has been the best time to bring people nervous to sing. Interestingly, every single person who's ever been to Festa with me who was intimidated by the Festa stage upon walking in never wanted to leave it after their debut song.

It's just an awesome discovery in a town where going out at night can be frosty, unfamiliar and too much of a scene.

None of that here. I hesitate to profess my love for Festa because I'm afraid it will become even more popular. But my love for this place (and appreciation given how great they've been to me and my friends) is the reason why I'm shouting from the rooftops. 

Go. Have fun. It's great.
author: Catherine P.

description:
Dark, swanky, sexy. . . excellent backdrop of lit up city skyline for singing Japanese karaoke.  I don't know about you guys, but I can't read or pronounce Japanese characters, so add that to the fact that I don't know any of the songs, and this will make for some damn obnoxious (or entertaining) karaoke.
Add it to the JTown Crawl.
**Update**
I'm going with damn obnoxious karaoke.  We did indeed add this spot to the JTown Crawl on Friday.  What I have only seen as a dark lounge filled with a couple of businessmen during the week, but have heard as a noisy hotspot on weekends or later in the evening, proved its hotspot chops.  But not with the crowd I'm used to seeing.  It seems to me that Silver Cloud got too crowded for some of the more SF savvy karaoksters and they've moved on to more intimate pastures.  Unfortunately for the rest of us.  
We perched at a corner table for just a moment before the waitress asked if we'd like to sit in the corner booth (which had a reserved sign on it).  Boy did we!  We snuggled in and placed our order and waited to watch some folks sing their hearts out.   I only made it through two lychee martinis (which were excellent, even if the lychees themselves were too sweet for me - canned it seems) and a little bowl of "outlines" which I ordered based on their name alone.  It's just snack mix - sesame stix, breadsticks, pretzels and nuts.  Why they call them outlines I have no idea, must be something lost in translation, but I love that they do.  It made them that much more delicious.  
As for enjoying the dulcet sounds of undiscovered American Idols, those dreams were shattered as we winced through our evening.  Two large groups of drunk and obnoxious white folk took turns singing, reading lyrics in monotone spoken word style, and/or screaming and grunting into the mics.   Luckily you need do nothing more than catch a bartenders roving eye and signal for another drink when you're dry.  If I had to get up and wade through the boisterous crowd and their cupcakey fingers I would've only had the one drink.
I think I'm only grousing because I was hoping for the quieter, more singing based karaoke experience I had seen on previous stops, instead of the Marina spillover screamfest/microphone fight we ended up with.  Oh and because we were the only couple in the entire place that didn't get offered birthday cupcakes.  What's up with that?  That's just mean.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
this is a japanofile mecca!  you can get your drink on and sing till your heart's desire.  you may even be able to pickup a kogaru if you try hard enough.

on any given night you may be able to spot a group of salarymen here for business, singing britney spear's songs.

prepare to dish out some okane, and expect some nihon style prices.....they charge per song

other than that...this place is awesome!
author: Ishmael V.

description:
let me tell you about the hazard that is Festa.

Suppose you go out with this guy and he totally surprises you by taking you to a kick-ass karaoke bar where the drinks are strong, the background is fittingly cheesy, and everyone is drunk and and singing along to the tone-deaf exhibitionist onstage. As you finish a round of drinks and get up to slur your way through a forgotten-favorite song, you think to yourself: this place is freakin' awesome.

A week or so later, you grab your friends and introduce them to this glorious world of alcohol-filled public embarrassment. And again, it is awesome beyond comprehension.

A few weeks pass, and you haven't been to Festa in a while. A visit is long overdue! You enter the tiny place, and to your horror you recognize more than half of the people there. You realize that, like wildfire or syphilis, word has spread from one friend to another, and before you know it, you're performing to a packed house of vague acquaintances and semi-friends.

Damnit, people, karaoke bars are for anonymous idiocy, where there is no fear of negative backlash or the need for damage control in the days following!

And thus, am I going to have to say: The first rule of Festa is: YOU DO NOT TALK ABOUT FESTA.

Thank you and goodnight.
author: Kerry N.

description: This is the funnest place. Yes, the drinks are pretty expensive, but it's just the cost of night life. I just wish there were more people who went there to sing who weren't so good. Everyone seemed to sing pretty good. Oh well, I still didn't mind singing badly. Yay. Oh, the song book was great, BUT, my only problem with it was it's organization was confusing. You could sit there for hours looking for stuff. Other than that minor issue, this place is a blast!
author: Sabina And Pete V.

description: This is the best place to sing Karaoke in SF. Small and intimate setting, it's about the size of one of the larger karaoke boxes in Tokyo. Staff is friendly and fun, song selection is very good in both English and Japanese. The overall atmosphere is very Japan-like, including the Tokyo pricing of the drinks, and their willingness to "over serve" their customers. What I like most about it is the people who go here are fun and cool, and everyone is getting their rock star on.
author: John D.

description: Fun atmosphere and great drinks. Gets crowded on the weekend but everyone is very cool so come early grab a drink and a seat and enjoy!
author: Stephanie R.

description: Came here w/ the sis as we were waiting for our table at Mum's.  We were actually pleasantly surprised as to how the place looked.  We chatted to our polite bartender about how the place is.  She said that it got pretty full on the weekends.  My sister asked her to make a drink and it came out wrong.  We asked her if she could fix it and gladly did w/ much apology.  We also had a lychee martini which was very tasty.  The karaoke book they had had everything under the sun from pop songs, love songs, songs in Chinese and Filipino!
author: Adrian D.

description: Festa is my favorite karaoke bar in SF. The cityscape backdrop is so cute! They have a great sound system, so you actually sound good and can hear yourself, unlike other places that have crappy mics and speakers. Pretty good song selection-they actually have two different books, so you might want to check them both if you're searching for a certain song. Ken, the bartender/server, always makes us feel welcome. The vibe is cozy and the crowd is friendly and supportive. Festa wa totemo subarashii, desu!
author: Miya K.

description: Karaoke brings out the inner rockstar supernova in all of us. A small group of friends and I dominated here last weekend for a birthday party. When I say dominated, the place is small and it is very easy to cruise in, feel comfy and get the party started. The atmosphere is intimate and  non-intimidating, which promotes everyone to sing, even those that should keep their lyrical talents private can be found screaming their asses of. It's a good mix of people, only problem is pricey drinks and $2.00 songs and ultra long waits. So if you plan on putting on a performance, better get a few songs lined up at once. All in all, fun experience, did someone say mic check 1...2...?
author: David P.

description: This much is "True"- Festa is "La Isla Bonita" for you and your folks after a long day of working "9 to 5". "I Swear" if you can get Festa all to yourselves, the stage is "Open Arms". Otherwise, when there are other parties that are filled with mic hogs, you're "Living on a Prayer" and Festa just becomes a plain ol' bar. The service is attentive and friendly even for the "Dancing Queens". The faux skyline backdrop on stage makes you "Hip to Be Square". (PS- apologies for the lame karaoke-ish review.)
author: Leroid D.

description: Very cool and friendly karoake bar in Japantown.  You have to look to find it.  Lots of locals, a full bar, and huge encyclopedia of music.  A very United Nations crowd.  It doesn't look like much, but just hanging out for a few minutes and you feel like you are with a group of your closest friends in Tokyo.
author: Laurence H.

description: Awesome place for a song and sake.  The bartenders are super nice.  I went there a few weeks back with my drunk buddette from the Lower Haight, gave the bartender a tip to bump us up the line for a song and lo and behold, my friend was too drunk to sing.    Then I went back last week and guess what...Marina folks!  A group of Banana Republic dress shirts/jeans guys and their Gap wearing girlfriends took over the right side of the bar being obnoxious and drunk.  The best part is everyone in the bar was laughing at them because they thought that they were so kool.
author: Christian N.

description: I think this place is pretty good...despite the really bad drinks.  The mixed crowed is great--from young hipsters to old fogies (like me).  It welcomes all.  I'm not a karaoke fan, but with a stage and "city lights" Festa is the place I could be converted.  But shaken manhattans and warm martinis at Tokyo prices don't help. With better bartenders, Festa could rock--even with an off pitch riff of Britney.
author: QuodE D.

description: we had a very similar experience to other reviews here., surprisingly high priced drinks for the atmosphere/service and extra drink charges on the bill.  The bartender also refused to fix the bill for us.
author: Mike R.

description:
As folks have mentioned, $2 a song, but what a selection!

They have a CyberDam system for all those who need to scratch the J-Pop itch (I'm a bit of a Hirai Ken junkie), and another system for more recent English songs. The Japanese system also has a better-than-average selection of songs in other languages.

If I'm in Japantown, it's a great follow-up to dinner.
author: Josh L.

description: Hey, sorry haven't been in the warbling mood for a while and since my singling tomodachi requested karaoke in J-town, thought this space would work and WOW...Sachi is now called FESTA...getcho FESTA on for a biggu biggu checkkkuuu. But it was FUN for once in a blue moon entertainment value. (But in reading the other guys reviews, beware of those screaming, obnoxiolla, amoebas crawling and drawling their bad juju into noFESTA,justaPesta.)
author: miriam b.

description: I know SF is an expensive place to live and run a business- but geeez! 6 dollar Sierra and 5 dollar BUD?? Im still giving them 3 stars because its a fun place to go with a nice decor.  I recommend getting there early to get a seat - and coming already tipsy will help your pocketbook.  The crowd was nice and friendly and the staff was good too.  I would go back when feeling like I didnt mind spending a hunk of cash to have fun time in a low key karaoke bar. By the way- they have a non-traditional song list so dont expect all your favorites will be there!
author: cece S.

description: The familiar warble of a karaoke song wafted out a nondescript set of doors, catching my attention as I was walking towards the parking garage. My curiosity was piqued, and I forged through the veneer to find myself transported to a bar in Tokyo. My friend was similarly delighted with the kitschy skyline decor and fabulously modern red chairs. We settled in quickly even though there weren't a lot of patrons around, and after a bottle of delightful sake called "poochi poochi" we took to the mike stand and never looked back. More of the bar's regulars strolled in later in the evening, and none shied away from belting out some classic oldies as well as more current tunes. I ended up spending a pretty penny there but I don't think I can say it wasn't worth it.
author: Yan Biao B.

description:
it was saturday night, I guess that makes it alright ...

actually it was "awesome".  went in at midnight and the place emptied out by 1 am and my friends and I pretty much had the entire place to ourselves.  A LOT cheaper than playground across the street but of course .. you have to share :(

it's a very small and the lighting is waay bright - they need to turn that down a notch.  If you are not comfortable being close enough to sit in someone's lap while you sing, this may not be the place for you.

the song selection is decent and they've got 2 books listed by artist which I like much better than listed by title.

if you are a heavy drinker, its gonna hurt - my last tab was $200+, next time I'm getting nackered somewhere else before heading there.

bartenders are very cool, I highly recommend buying them shots :D
author: adam b.

description: This was the second time I've been to this "establishment". The first time me and my friends had a wonderful time. We were enjoying our drinks and performances. But last night... wow... me and my friends (the same ones from last time) decided to come here after a late dinner for some drinks and entertainment. Boy were we in for a treat! We came in it was pretty empty which we didnt think much of because it was a Wednesday night. This man (theres a picture of him in all black wearing a hat) came to seat us, we really didnt need his help being that only 2 tables were being occupied (we were waiting for the rest of our party, but we followed him to the table. He giggled and made our party show ID. So we were looking through the book of songs from "Septemeber 2008" and the waitress came over to take our drink orders. 2 people in our party didnt want to drink but she said "there's a one drink minimum" (which we didnt have before) so they ordered drinks and we moved on. So we waited a little while for our drinks, when they came the waitress spilled one of them on my friend. I had a mojito that was VERY watery and small for $9. Before we could finish our drinks she came to ask us about our bill. 2 people were together and the other 3 were with me. She came back with 3 checks, i had my card out already so i grabbed my two checks and handed it back to her... My other friend decided to keep her tab opened. So the waitress returned with my reciept I signed it. Left no tip becuz I was planning on leaving cash after I was done drinking. The waitress took the check. After the males in our group stepped out for a smoke, the giggling man came to our table and told me "Um, you didnt leave a  tip"; I told him "I know, I was going to leave cash when Im done" He then says "This is America, you need to leave a 20% tip!" Um... I don't recall seeing that in the constitution, so my response of shock and laughter was understandable. When our other friends come back we tell them the story and they laugh. So Im still there sipping on my mint water when one of our friends goes to get one more drink and to close their tab. The giggling man told him "Make sure she gives a tip" which my friend tells me. His wife is going over their tab and they were charged extra money. So we approach the bar because we are leaving; they tell her they charged her $3 tax for keeping their tab open... Now, to me this is something that  they should had stated when they decided to keep the tab open. So, in the end they over charged my friend and recieved no tip from me because they were very rude by asking me for a tip when I was not leaving. Guess I we will have to just find a neww spot because I will never be back to this place ever again!
author: Jo C.

description:
Went here with a couple of former colleages from Japan here on a business trip. We got here early on a Saturday night ~7.30pm. The place was almost empty, just a couple of others. We got in about 6 songs each before it filled up quickly at around 9pm. This place is small so it fills up fast and you won't be singing many songs after that.
Sound system was definately sub-par though compared to what I'm used to (7bamboo in San Jose Japantown is way superior). Mikes are sub-standard and they had the echo up way too high. Also, music level was often much too high, drowning out the singers voice. I had to ask the barman to turn down the music on some of my more quieter numbers. Place seems pretty friendly, staff OK. Can't comment on the cost as my Japanese colleagues paid but $2/song isn't too unreasonable I guess for Japantown. (7Bamboo in SJ charges $1 for a song). They had a huge collection of Japanese songs which was great.
author: Chris P.

description:
Such RUDE people... 

Here's what exactly the people working there saying: 

"ok, we fuck'in lost your song... if you can write down the song number again we will put it in the queue..." 

Ugh... after waiting there for 2 hours ordering drinks and tipping the bar tenders big time, and wondering what was going on, this is our answer for keeping us waiting forever? After such long wait and horrible service/attitude, who still wants to continue to sing there? 
I ordered 3 songs at the same time, 2 of them played after about waiting there for an hour. I went up there saying that I ordered 3 songs all at the same time, is the 3rd one forgotten? and put down the 4th one. I was told that she could not play my songs all the time had to play others too, so I had to wait, it would be my turn after another 6 songs. After 6 songs, I went up there and asked again, she said it would be mine the next. After another a few rounds seeing others singing back to back, we thought it was not right. I went up there for the 3rd time to ask, the gal who was in charge of running the songs said: "see others were tipping us and you never give us tips!" AH...there were reasons behind it...  So we explained that we had been tipping the bar tenders big time... however, apparently, she randomly throw out my 3rd song, it was no longer even in the queue any more... 

At that point, we felt so sick with these rude people. We asked for refund - really rather not to deal with them... she threw the money on the counter with another one song's refund short... 

I will never return that place again. If you do not want to ruin your fun night, don't ever bother go there.
author: Jas W.

description: We've been to this place twice and  our experience could not have been more different. The first time we went, we found it to be one of the only authentic karaoke bars in Japantown that did not serve as a brothel on the side and we had a terrific time singing with the owner and buying our $6-$8 drinks. However, we went there tonight with a group of friends and when our final tab came, the bartender took the priveledge of charging us $10 a drink, added on drinks that we paid in cash to our friends' tab, and charged us $2 a song without ever notifying us of the "karaoke song" charge in the first place. We will never go there again and would advise likewise.
author: Lauren H.

description: I looooooove this place!!!! I have been to quite a few karaoke joints and this one, I have to say, hands down, makes me feel so comfortable and at home and I keep wanting to go back. I love that it's sort of hidden, off the beaten path. It's kind of small and cozy...not intimidating for non-pro singers if you get my drift. The staff is very attentive, classy and also fun. They sometimes sing themselves! The drinks are really well done. I get a lemon drop ever time...done to perfection. This place is in my neighborhood which I love. I have had many many friends come here and we've all had the best time. Each night is slightly different of course. Weekends are more crowded and get big groups sometimes. Weekdays are nice, a mixture of people just getting off there bartending/waitressing jobs nearby, people staying at the nearby hotel and locals wandering in. EVERYTIME I have been here, what I have been impressed by is the support of the crowd. It can be all types of people, old and young, all ethnicities and we're all cheering each other on whether good or bad. It's a real confidence booster to get on stage and sing your heart out and have adoring fans around. A real nice way to let loose. I did read some of the other reviews on here before I wrote this and I almost wish I didn't because I'm saddened to see how they diss the staff. You have to know this staff deals with people yelling into the mic and getting a bit carried away in intoxication at times. They are trying to accommodate new comers and trying to please everyone. So I don't find it unreasonable that they accommodate as they see appropriate. I am so happy and proud to have this relatively new restaurant in my neighborhood. It is one of the finer new establishments to bring the Fillmore district back to life in a positive sense. I have come here for brunch, dinner dates, a company Christmas party, for the drinks at the bar and for apps and drinks in the lounge area. I love decor: the historical jazz pictures with the light behind them on the walls, the unique decorative hanging lamps, and the dark wood. I really like the way this place sections off to make it more intimate whether for private parties or if it's not that buy and they close off certain sections. Oh, the music is jazzy of course. Romantic, classic, soulful, happy and fun. The staff are cheery, helpful and knowledgeable. Ok, the best for last...the food is AMAZING! I have gotten the pork main (YUM!), the shrimp and grits app (YUM!) and the butternut squash soup (YUM again!). I've gotten a lot more than that but that's what comes to mind..haven't had anything bad or even mediocre there basically. This a really classy without being pretentious place and I highly recommend you go there NOW!
author: Keri R.

description: This is a great local place to have fun!  I went there last night and it was consistent with the previous times I've been....tons of fun, great vibe and energy, the wine and cocktails were great (yes, I sing better after knocking back a couple), and the service was fantastic.  Plus, it's a perfect place to meet  a bunch of friends to sing your hearts away!
author: How L.

description: I went back to festa lounge again. Every time I go there I have such a great time. I don't sing!! but still great place to hang out friends. I love people who works there. I love there even you are alone, you can enjoy a cocktail.
author: neko c.

description: Tuesday night. Jtown is quiet. Eat sushi. Wander the empty halls. 9pm. Doorway seeps dark energy. Pulled in. Koji cleans glasses. Kim at usual spot. Three red wines. Nobody singing yet. Make that two wines, one Sapporo. Chatter in Japanese. Koji laughs. Nice to see you again. Green Day comes on. Remember last time? Yukiko pulls my arm. Do you have the time? To listen to me whine? Dance like Jagger. More Sapporo. Koji plays a Gibson SG. Older Japanese guy sings. Respectful lull. Devastatingly sad song. Applause. 11pm. Yukiko is a pilot? And a bartender? Sachiko is given the mike. I didn't know you could sing! You're a nightingale! Elvis has entered the building. Air guitar on Yukiko's leg. Kim loves Elvis. Harmonies on Lauryn Hill. Club soda, then more wine. 1am. Finger food. Promise you'll fly me to Vegas? I'll totally do it. Another sad song. Quiet. Old man has heart! AC-DC. Devil horns, rock faces. We salute you. Gulp down Sapporo. Goodbye, thanks. Come to my gig. I didn't know you could sing? Vegas, we're doing it. Stumble to cab. Daydream on the way home.
author: andy d.
